content.title: PURE Way Playbook

mainContent.text: The PURE WayResource Center PURE Way Playbook V1.6Revised July 2024Search the PURE Way PlaybookMac users press Command + F             Windows users press CTRL + FTable of ContentsSection 1: PURE Way Playbook OverviewSection 2: Corporate PoliciesSection 3: Operational StandardsSection 4: Applicable Laws and RegulationsSection 5: Standard Operating ProceduresSection 6: AppendixSection 1: PURE Way Playbook Overview IntroductionLegal DisclaimerCorporate Vision and ValuesRegulatory OversightDocument Control ProcedureRevision ProcessChange NotificationPURE Way Playbook Change Request FormIntroductionPURE Property Management’s vision is to make the joy of renting a home PURE and to provide a simple and satisfying experience for all. To support this vision, the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual outlines the policies, processes, and procedures that drive every aspect of the PURE Way experience. All PURE operations team members are required to be familiar with the subject matter contained in the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual and abide by all outlined policies, processes, and procedures.Please note that this manual is subject to periodic revision. All members of team PURE should remain aware of and review any changes to this manual as they occur. If discrepancies are discovered or if there are any questions, it is the responsibility of each team member to raise their concern to their direct supervisor for clarification.Legal DisclaimerThe information contained within this document is proprietary, confidential, and for internal use only. No part of the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual may be printed, reproduced, or distributed without the express written consent of PURE Property Management, its representatives, or assignees.PURE team members are not permitted to disclose the information contained within this document to Clients, Residents, Vendors, or the public, nor are they permitted to disclose any trade secrets of PURE Property Management including but not limited to management fees, commissions, referrals, and any other fees or associated programs; financial information; personnel compensation; personnel records; personnel conversations; Client records or conversations; management accounts; real estate sales or listings; marketing and/or strategic plans; or company projects, except as is required while performing the duties of their role within PURE Property Management.Corporate Vision and ValuesLed by a team of experienced property management industry professionals and seasoned technology innovators, PURE Property Management combines over 2,000 years of collective property management experience with the vision of leveraging world-class technology to deliver simple, satisfying experiences for all.PURE values are what bands team PURE together in the mission of innovating property management.Keep it SIMPLEComplexity is the enemy. We strive for clean, simple, tech-driven solutions that deliver exceptional experiences.Keep it REALWe’re genuine, independent, yet united. We’re proud of who we are, know where we’re going and how to get there.Keep it HONESTEveryone trusts us to do the right, responsible thing with integrity and responsiveness. Never afraid to admit a mistake.Keep it KINDWe’re kind, caring, and compassionate. We strive for work-life balance, with family always a priority.BAND together (n+1)Strength and success are found in greater numbers. We’re driven to grow our team of independent Rockstars.BUILD togetherBy creating new technology and mashing up our collective hits, we build and deliver fresh, industry-leading experiences.PLAY togetherCollaboration is key to success. No solo artists on this label. We find the fun when we play well with each other.WIN togetherOur success is clearly defined, well-played, and thoughtfully measured. We strive to empower and hold ourselves accountable.The policies, processes, and procedures outlined in the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual represent PURE’s best practices to standardize operations for all teams within the PURE family in alignment with PURE Corporate Values.Regulatory OversightResidential property management activities are strictly regulated by several federal agencies, including the:Internal Revenue Service (IRS)US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)Federal Trade Commission (FTC)US Department of Justice (DOJ)The policies, processes, and procedures within the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual are designed to ensure compliance with all federal regulations. Each member of Team PURE is personally responsible for ensuring that these policies, processes, and procedures are followed.Further information regarding applicable laws and regulations may be found in Section 3 of the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual.Document Control ProcedureThe PURE Way Playbook is the single source of PURE Way Policy and Procedure for the operations of PURE Property Management. This document is subject to revision, and revision to this document must be made under the following Standard Operating Procedure.Change RequestsChange Requests are submitted via the Change Request Form.Change Requests are reviewed by the PURE Way Team for disposition and prioritization.Does the change require a version change?Is this a system or software-driven change?Does this change require additional or re-training?Change Requests can be used to request the creation of a new document or to document a process that has not yet been documented. Changes related to typographical errors, grammatical errors, punctuation, or broken hyperlinks will not require a version change or Change Notification.Revision ProcessThe Revision Process must include the PURE Way Technical Writer, Christina Heldwein; Subject Matter Expert(s), Key Stakeholder(s), the Approver(s), and at least one member of the PURE Way Team.When a revision is necessary, the document(s) requiring changes will be isolated and revised with the Secondary Stakeholders and the Technical Writer. A Google Doc with limited access will be used for revision development.New and Revised Documents submitted for the PURE Way Playbook must be processed for publishing.Change NotificationThe audience defined for each Policy, Process, or Procedure indicates the primary operators to notify of a document change.Playbook Versioning NotificationPlaybook Versioning requires a written notice to destroy all previous versions of any documents contained within the PlaybookSOP and P&P Change NotificationRegulation Changes, Operational/ Task-related changes, or System-driven changes must be communicated to the appropriate audiences at the time of publication. Change Notifications will be sent to the Key Stakeholders for distribution to the defined audience.PURE Way Playbook Change Request FormAs you know, the PURE Way Playbook is a thoughtful culmination of the most successful property management operations and a major training focus for 2024.  Totaling over 300 pages, with policies and step-by-step guides, we feel it’s pretty comprehensive.  That said, maybe we missed something.  Is there a gap in a process, or something we didn’t think of?  Did you spot a typo?  As you interact with the playbook, let us know.  Use the form below to submit a request to correct or modify an existing section of the current Playbook as we continue to build the PURE Way.Section 2: Corporate Policies Diversity and InclusionPolicy Against Harassment, Discrimination, and RetaliationEqual Employment OpportunityCode of EthicsStandards of ConductSafetyEmergenciesSecurity and ConfidentialityDocument Use, Storage, and DispositionMedia Inquiry PolicyUse of Company Owned Vehicles and EquipmentCompany Logo and Marketing MaterialsRoles and Responsibilities of PURE Centralized OperationsDiversity and InclusionAs stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, PURE is committed to providing a work environment for all members of Team PURE that is welcoming, respectful, and engaging, with opportunities for personal and professional development. Having diverse teams, business partners and community relationships is vital to the spirit of collaboration and innovation that drives organic growth and success.Policy Against Harassment, Discrimination, and RetaliationPURE is committed to providing all applicants and team members with a safe and respectful working environment that is free from sexual harassment, as well as harassment and discrimination on the basis of actual or perceived race (including but not limited to the wearing of natural hairstyles such as afros, braids, twists, and locks), color, national origin, ancestry, religion, creed (including religious dress and grooming), citizenship status, sex or gender (including pregnancy, childbirth, and related medical conditions), gender identity or gender expression (including transgender status), sexual orientation, age, marital status, military service or veteran status, legally protected medical condition, physical or mental disability, genetic information, or any other characteristics under federal, state or local laws and ordinances (referred to as “protected characteristics”).PURE maintains a strict policy that forbids sexual harassment and other harassment and discrimination against applicants or employees by co-workers, supervisors, managers, and professionals; furthermore, PURE will not tolerate harassment by its employees or non-employees with whom PURE has a business, service, or professional relationship, nor harassment of employees by non-employees, such as Clients, Vendors, contingent workers, and guests.This policy applies at all company locations, company-sponsored social or other events, and other activities at which team PURE is represented. It applies to all areas of employment, including recruiting, hiring, placement, training, promotion, compensation, benefits, transfer, disciplinary action, employee activities, access to facilities and programs, general treatment during employment, and social and recreational programs. It is the personal responsibility of each member of Team PURE to be familiar with and abide by this policy.All members of Team PURE are encouraged to report any incidents of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation immediately so that complaints can be quickly and fairly resolved. For guidance on complaint reporting and investigation, please refer to the PURE Employee Handbook.Equal Employment OpportunityPURE is an Equal Opportunity Employer that does not discriminate on the basis of actual or perceived race (including but not limited to the wearing of natural hairstyles such as afros, braids, twists, and locks), color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, citizenship status, age, sex or gender (including pregnancy), gender identity or expression (including transgender status), sexual orientation, marital status, veteran status, physical or mental disability, genetic information, or any other characteristic protected by applicable federal, state, or local laws.It is PURE company policy to recruit, employ, retain, promote, terminate, and otherwise treat all team members and job applicants based on merit, qualifications, and competence. It is a violation of PURE policy to discriminate in the provision of employment opportunities, benefits, or privileges; to create discriminatory work conditions; or to use discriminatory evaluative standards in employment, if that discriminatory treatment is, in whole or in part, based on actual or perceived protected characteristics.All members of Team PURE are encouraged to report any incidents of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation immediately so that complaints can be quickly and fairly resolved. For guidance on complaint reporting and investigation, please refer to the PURE Employee Handbook.Code of EthicsPURE conducts its affairs in strict compliance with the letter and spirit of the law and adherence to the highest principles of business ethics. Accordingly, all members of Team PURE must avoid activities that are in conflict, or give the appearance of being in conflict, with these principles and with the interests of the PURE. A conflict of interest exists when the team member’s loyalties or actions are divided between PURE interests and those of another, such as a competitor, supplier, or customer. Both the fact and the appearance of a conflict of interest should be avoided. Members of team PURE unsure as to whether a certain transaction, activity, or relationship constitutes a conflict of interest should discuss it with their immediate supervisor or the Managing Partners for clarification.Standards of ConductThe list outlined below is derived directly from the PURE Employee Handbook and provides examples of types of conduct that are not allowed at PURE. Engaging in misconduct of a type specifically designated here, or as otherwise described in the PURE Employee Handbook, may subject the engaging team member to disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. These examples do not identify every type of unacceptable conduct, and team members should be aware that any conduct detrimental to the interests of PURE, other team members, Residents, or Clients may result in disciplinary action up to and including immediate discharge.Falsifying forms, records, reports, or other acts of dishonesty - PURE will not tolerate any falsified or misleading disclosures in company records, or the destruction, manipulation, or intentional misplacement of such records.Excessive unexcused absenteeism or tardiness not otherwise protected by applicable law.Poor performance, including refusal to perform lawful assigned tasks.Engaging in altercations or harassment and interfering with the work performance of others.Engaging in violent behavior, threats of violence, or any persistent malicious behavior that is known to have a high correlation to violent behavior, such as abusive conduct, intimidation, or conduct that demeans, degrades, or humiliates other employees.Misusing or destroying PURE property or the property of another on PURE premises.Failing to protect and respect all intellectual property belonging to the company or its Vendors, customers, partners, or business associates; i.e. the unauthorized use, copying, distribution, or alteration of company software or other intellectual property, or the intellectual property or third-party property of others entrusted to the company.Violating duties of confidentiality.Conducting non-business activities during the time paid by PURE and/or with PURE materials.Possessing or bringing firearms or other dangerous weapons onto PURE premises.Violating safety or health regulations, or otherwise engaging in conduct that creates a hazard.Violating conflict of interest rules.Being convicted of a crime that indicates unfitness for the job or raises a threat to the safety or well-being of PURE, its employees, customers, or property, to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law.Non-compliance with company policies, including but not limited to policies contained in this manual, such as the Conflict of Interest Policy and Policy Against Harassment.Non-compliance with all laws, rules, and regulations wherever the company does business.PURE expects team members to be ethical, responsible, and in compliance with all applicable laws when conducting business or otherwise acting as a representative of the company.SafetyAs stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, it is of the utmost importance to PURE that safe working conditions are maintained for all team members, and that all team members remain safety conscious.Any potential safety hazards at any site where PURE may conduct business should be reported immediately to management. Any injury, no matter how minor, during the course of employment must be reported promptly to the team member’s direct supervisor. Any member of team PURE who is injured on the job should seek medical treatment immediately.In compliance with applicable law and to promote the concept of a safe workplace PURE maintains an Injury and Illness Prevention Program.EmergenciesTo protect the life and safety of PURE team members in the event of an emergency, PURE has developed an Emergency Action Plan applicable to all PURE locations, available for review at the PURE Way Resource Center. All members of team PURE should review this Emergency Action Plan carefully.Security and ConfidentialityThe security of PURE property and team members is critical and can be maintained only with the cooperation of all employees. Any breach of security should be immediately reported to management.PURE property includes not only items such as computers and desks but also its proprietary and confidential information. Confidential information is of great importance to the future of PURE’s business, and it is the duty of each member of team PURE to maintain confidentiality even if the employment relationship with PURE ends. Prospective, current, and former members of team PURE are not to disclose any PURE confidential information to any person unless specifically authorized by PURE. Confidential information includes but is not limited to customer lists, computer records, financial data, details of engagement, process descriptions, technical and business information, research and development, production, manufacturing and engineering processes, finances, customers, and marketing and production and future business plans of PURE.Team members are expected, as a condition of employment, to sign PURE’s At-Will Employment Confidential Information, Invention, and Assignment Agreement setting forth these duties in detail. Nothing in this section is intended to prohibit team members from discussing their own terms and conditions of employment.Document Use, Storage, and DispositionPolicies outlined in this section of the PURE Way Operations and Policy Manual apply to all PURE Property Management documents without exception. Each department follows specific processes designed to best suit the regulatory requirements of its operations and location.For all documents not stored within a PMS:When a document has reached its respective maturity date, discard the document electronically or physically.Property Management and Leasing DocumentsDocuments that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by system definitions approved by the PURE Way Team.Documents that are not utilized or processed through a PMS are retained on their office-specific Google Drive for a minimum of 3 years, or in accordance with state/local law.Accounting Documents Documents that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by system definitions approved by the PURE Way Team.Documents that are not utilized or processed through a PMS are retained on a designated Google Drive for a minimum of 6 months, or in accordance with state/local law.Human ResourcesPURE Human Resources follows state and federal record retention guidelines.Personnel files are maintained for a minimum of 4 years after the end of employment.Employment applications are kept on file for a minimum of 1 year after disposition.OSHA logs and Injury Reports are maintained for a minimum of 5 years after the reporting period.California record retention practices currently cover all states in which PURE operates. In the event that guidelines exceeding the stringency of California are identified, PURE Human Resources will act to remain in compliance.The information recorded in each member of team PURE’s personnel file is extremely important both to the team members and to management. It is each team member’s responsibility to make sure that the personal data in the file is accurate and up to date.PURE does not disclose any nonpublic personal information about our team members or former team members to anyone, except as authorized by the team member or as required or permitted by law. PURE maintains physical, electronic, and procedural safeguards that comply with federal standards to safeguard nonpublic personal information.MaintenanceDocuments that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by definitions approved by PURE Property Management.OSHA logs and Injury Reports are maintained for a minimum of 5 years after the reporting period.Media Inquiry PolicyAll public relations activities and media requests regarding PURE will be coordinated and managed to ensure the dissemination of only accurate and appropriate information to the public and to provide a positive, professional appearance of PURE and PURE products. Therefore, all media inquiries regarding the position of PURE as to any issues must be referred to a PURE-authorized spokesperson. Only the approved spokespersons are authorized to make or approve public statements on behalf of PURE. No member of team PURE, unless specifically designated, is authorized to make statements on behalf of the company. Any member of team PURE wishing to write and/or publish an article, paper, blog, or other publication on behalf of PURE must first obtain approval from PURE.Nothing in this policy is meant to, nor should it be interpreted to, in any way limit the rights of any member of Team PURE under any applicable federal, state, or local laws, including rights under the National Labor Relations Act to engage in protected concerted activities with other team members to improve terms and conditions of employment, such as wages and benefits.Use of Company Owned Vehicles and EquipmentAs stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, PURE may provide vehicles for business use to allow employees to drive on company-designated business. The company may also reimburse employees for business use of personal vehicles according to the guidelines below. The company retains the right to amend or terminate this policy at any time. The term “vehicle” as used in this policy includes but is not limited to cars, trucks, SUVs, and other types of vehicles considered to be “street legal” according to traffic laws in the United States.Team members may not drive any company vehicles without the prior approval of their direct supervisor. Members of team PURE approved to drive on company business are required to inform their supervisor of any changes that may affect either their legal or physical ability to drive or their continued insurability. Team members holding jobs requiring regular driving for business as an essential job function must, as a condition of employment, be able to meet the driver approval standards of this policy at all times.Members of team PURE who drive a vehicle on company business must, in addition to meeting the approval requirements above, exercise due diligence to drive safely and to maintain the security of the vehicle and its contents. This includes not using the vehicle in a manner prohibited by the vehicle manufacturer. The use of handheld cell phones while behind the wheel of a moving vehicle being used on company business is strictly prohibited. Team members are solely responsible for any driving infractions or fines as a result of their driving.Non-employees and non-business passengers are prohibited from riding in company vehicles. Team members must report any accident, theft, or malicious damage involving a company vehicle to their supervisor and Human Resources, regardless of the extent of damage or lack of injuries.Company vehicles must be inspected quarterly; such inspection shall utilize a Vehicle Inspection Form available from Human Resources for the team member and that team member’s direct supervisor to fill out for submission to the company. The installation or addition of performance enhancements, alterations, or other after-market accessories to company vehicles are strictly prohibited.Company Logo and Marketing MaterialsAll marketing materials must be approved by a PURE Marketing team member. Reach out to the #ask-marketing channel on Slack for assistance, to obtain proofs. or for approval if you're creating marketing or operational collateral involving brand identity. Style GuideDO/OK|DO NOT/AVOID PURE Property Management[Location] OfficePURE Property ManagementNorth Bay OfficePURE Property Management of [State]PURE Property Management of CaliforniaPURE is always upper case.|Pure Property Management | North BayPURE Property Management of North BayPURE Property Management | North Bay, Inc.PURE Property Management of CAPure Property Management of CAPURE Property Mgmt | North BayPURE Property | North BayPURE Property Management, North BayPURE Property Management - North BayPure North BayPURE Family of CompaniesPowered by PUREPurePM or PURE PMPure is never lowercase.Never abbreviate MGMTPURE Property Management, Inc. in legal documents or situations where the legal entity name, not the DBA, is required.|PURE Property Management (absent the Inc.) in documents or situations where the legal operating name is required.Abbreviate PURE after 1st mention of PURE Property Management in copy.Example:Hi, I’m reaching you on behalf of PURE Property Management. Check the PURE Way Brand Center in the PURE Way Resource Center for more details! Roles and Responsibilities of PURE Centralized OperationsRegional DirectorThe Regional Director is responsible for leading and managing the Operators and/or Operations Managers of multiple offices, in many cases across large regions or states, to achieve business goals and maximize profitability. The purpose of the Regional Director of Operations is to effectively guide leaders in the assigned geographic area, set performance objectives, evaluate and optimize operational performance, ensure company standards are upheld, and prepare operations and financial reports.Operations ManagerThe Operations Manager is accountable for all office operations. The Operations Manager effectively manages and coordinates persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish property objectives as set forth by PURE. The Operations Manager will participate in the creation and implementation of strategies, operational procedures, and policy development.Senior Property ManagerThe Senior Property Manager is accountable for all property operations. The purpose of the Senior Property Manager is to effectively manage and coordinate persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish company objectives in concert with objectives set forth by the Client. These objectives include maximizing occupancy levels and property values. The Senior Property Manager is the direct point of contact for PURE Clients.Property ManagerThe Property Manager works as a key player on the property management team to deliver exceptional service to Residents in their assigned portfolio. The purpose of the Property Manager is to effectively manage and coordinate persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish company objectives while creating a superb Resident experience. The Property Manager is the direct point of contact for PURE Residents.Assistant Property ManagerThe Assistant Property Manager assists the Property Manager with Client satisfaction and retention by promoting Resident relations through ongoing follow-through and communication in all aspects of the property management cycle. The Assistant Property Manager maintains excellent Resident relations while assisting the Property Manager in communicating with Residents, both verbally and in writing.Business Development RepresentativeThe Business Development Representative is accountable for all organic Client growth and new property onboarding. The Business Development Representative must effectively market PURE Property Management services, generate leads on prospective Clients, contact prospective Clients, present company services, and secure new management contracts. The Business Development Representative must be able to relate to all people, have a Client-first attitude, possess a high degree of professional and ethical standards, and carry out duties with prompt execution and exceptional follow-through.Leasing SpecialistThe Leasing Specialist is accountable for promoting properties, responding to inquiries, qualifying prospective tenants, processing applications according to company-established policies in a timely manner, and maximizing occupancy levels. The Leasing Specialist must display tech-savviness, great communication, organizational, and sales skills. As the face of PURE Property Management, a friendly and helpful demeanor is essential to being successful in this position.Maintenance CoordinatorThe Maintenance Coordinator assists the property management team with client satisfaction and retention by promoting resident relations through ongoing follow-through and communication in all aspects of the property management cycle. The Maintenance Coordinator maintains excellent resident relations when communicating with residents and owners, answering inquiries about maintenance request status, approval of estimates, and general recommendations.After Hours Maintenance Services RepresentativeThe After Hours Maintenance Services Representative assists the property management team with client satisfaction and retention by communicating with residents and owners, answering  inquiries about maintenance request status, and dispatching emergency maintenance services after normal business hours.Field TechnicianThe Maintenance Field Technician responds to PURE Property Management resident service requests with a professional demeanor, in a timely fashion and is a driving force behind exceptional customer service. A general knowledge of maintenance functions such as basic plumbing, electric, and carpentry skills are required. A keen eye for detail, effective communication with residents both written and verbal, organization, and physical stamina are important qualities for this position.Operations Staff AccountantThe Staff Accountant provides accounting support for one or more PURE Property Management locations to accomplish company goals and objectives and conducts all PURE accounting transactions as defined by the policies and procedures established by the PURE Finance/Accounting Department and Trust Accounting and Compliance Department. Policies may vary by state as established by licensing authorities and trust account compliance requirements or by HOA as established by Board requests, association needs, and/or governing documents.Section 3: Operational StandardsThe PURE Resident Benefits PackageThe PURE Animal ProgramThe PURE Security Deposit Replacement ProgramSelf-Access Property ShowingsVendor ManagementVendor Invoicing PolicyManaging Negative Feedback and ComplaintsAcceptable Forms of PaymentMold, Mildew, and Lead-Based PaintResident Illness, Hospitalization, or DeathSmoke Alarms, and Carbon Monoxide DetectorsThe PURE Resident Benefits PackageA Resident Benefits Package (RBP) is a collection of services and amenities that a renter can only get from a professional management company. As a condition of allowing Residents to have pets at a property, where allowable by state or local law:Residents with animals will be required to have any carpets professionally cleaned, deodorized, and treated for fleas and provide evidence of said cleaning/treatment upon Move-OutAn annual property evaluation will be performed at a cost to the ResidentIn accordance with federal guidance, Residents with an Assistance Animal will never be asked to pay any fees applicable to pets under the Animal Program. Animal Program FeesUp-Front Fees Due at Lease SigningPet Administration Fee: $400 for the first pet; $250 per additional pet thereafterTank/Cage Pet Administration Fee*: $250 per enclosure*for animals like fish and birds, which would be kept in tanks/cagesMonthly FeesFIDO Score™ of 3 or higher: $30/month, per petFIDO Score™ 2: $50/month, per petFIDO Score™of 1:  $80/month, per petAnimals that cannot be assigned a FIDO Score™ through PetScreening (e.g., fish and birds) will be considered as having a FIDO Score™ of 3.Annual FeesAnnual Property Evaluation: $75PetScreening Profile Renewal*: $25 paid to PetScreening*only pet owners will need to pay the profile renewal fee as Assistance Animal and no-pet profiles renew at no cost to the ResidentGL Codes4470 Monthly Pet Fee4475 Annual Pet Evaluation4480 Non-Refundable Pet FeeNote: If your local or state law limits or dictates a maximum allowable upfront and/or recurring fee, please share this information with the PURE Way Team.The Enhanced Damage ProgramPURE Property Management offers the Enhanced Damage Program (EDP) to all Owners who agree to allow PURE to offer their property as “pets negotiable” or “pet friendly.'' As a part of this program, PURE agrees to repair any documented pet damage, up to $2,000 per lease, for pet damages exceeding the Resident's Security Deposit or SDRP coverage. Security Deposit and/or SDRP funds must be exhausted as a condition precedent to triggering the EDP.The Enhanced Damage Program only applies to leases that have PURE-approved and registered pets. Undisclosed and unauthorized pets are not included in the EDP. Additionally, any damage caused by Assistance Animals is not covered under the EDP and is the sole responsibility of the Resident.The EDP is terminated immediately upon termination of the management agreement between the property Owner and PURE PM.Unauthorized AnimalsUnauthorized animals discovered on a property are considered a lease violation, and where permitted by law, can be grounds to begin the eviction process.If a Resident fails to disclose an animal at any point during the term of the Residential Rental Agreement, at the office’s discretion the Resident may be allowed to complete the animal screening process to certify any unauthorized animal. The Resident will be obligated to pay a $100 processing fee, plus the lesser of all applicable pet fees associated with the screening of the animal and all monthly pet fees back to the Residential Rental Agreement inception date or a $500 fee.The PURE Security Deposit Replacement ProgramThe Security Deposit Replacement Program (SDRP) offers Residents a choice between paying thetraditional security deposit or paying a non-refundable monthly fee for the duration of their occupancy instead. The monthly fee is not held by PURE, but paid to YRIG for Security Deposit Insurance on which PURE is the insured party.To qualify for enrollment in the SDRP, new applicants must have a fully-approved rental application. Applicants who are approved with conditions are not eligible for the SDRP during their first year of Residency, but may become eligible at renewal based upon their performance as a Resident.Residents remain legally responsible for damages, repairs, and fees and PURE is protected from losses in the event that the Resident refuses to pay. The SDRP coverage amount - the “Band level” - is calculated at 1x the monthly rent, rounded up to the next $500 increment. For properties that are not accessible for self-showings, e.g., a home in a gated community, showings will be conducted by appointment only.Barring extenuating circumstances, the applicant or a representative of the applicant is required to view the property in person prior to submitting an application.Vendor ManagementVendors used for repairs, maintenance, and property management are all screened and approved as PURE Vendors. In order to become a PURE Vendor, the Vendor must provide:A completed PURE Vendor Onboarding WorksheetCurrent business license(s), in accordance with federal and state requirementsProof of Liability Insurance, COI at $1,000,000A certificate holder for the office locationA completed W9A completed ACH Form for direct depositWhere applicable, proof of Worker’s Compensation Insurance at $1,000,000It is the Vendor’s responsibility to provide PURE with renewed licenses, insurance policies, and updated tax or banking information. The Maintenance Coordinator is responsible for verifying and entering the updated information in PURE’s Vendor database(s).PURE requires a standard of service and Client/Resident experience from all PURE Vendors, measured upon the following principles:Workmanship QualityIn the event that a Vendor shows a pattern of recurring negligence, poor workmanship, code/ regulation non-compliance, or otherwise insufficient service, PURE reserves the right to remove that Vendor from the PURE platform.Market Value AlignmentPURE selects Vendors with consideration to their alignment with the current local market for the costs of materials and labor.Timely and Accurate BillingVendors are required to comply with the PURE Vendor Invoicing Policy, and a pattern of inaccurate or untimely billing may result in removal from the PURE platform.AvailabilityA Vendor with limited availability, or who shows a pattern of frequent cancellations may be removed from the PURE platform.The Maintenance Coordinator is responsible for tracking Vendor pricing and patterns of negative Resident feedback, poor workmanship, and lapses of required documentation. In the event of aberration from PURE’s standard of service, the Maintenance Coordinator is authorized to recommend corrective action to the Vendor or to recommend the Vendor's removal from the PURE platform to their direct supervisor.Vendor Invoicing PolicyAll invoices must be submitted to PURE through PropertyMeld. Vendors are requested to issue one invoice per work order. Invoices should be charged for the full amount of the work order, except where there is a written agreement by both parties confirming a specific arrangement of invoicing.Invoice ContentIn accordance with IRS requirements, all invoices must include the following:The title “Invoice” clearly displayedPURE office name (e.g., PURE Property Management - North Bay Office)Invoice datePayment termsA unique invoice numberA description of the products or services soldThe quantity and price of each product/serviceThe date that products/services were deliveredThe total amount dueSales tax, where applicablePURE Property Management will return any invoices that do not contain these items, as they are not in compliance with IRS guidelines.Invoice PaymentUnless otherwise agreed upon and specified on the invoice, PURE Property Management will render payment within 30 days of receiving the invoice. PURE Property Management does not approve rolling unpaid charges to another invoice number.Managing Negative Feedback and ComplaintsAs soon as negative feedback or a complaint is received, it must be escalated to the office Operations Manager for attention. The Operations Manager will proceed with managing the matter based on the nature of the feedback or the complaint. The PURE Way Corporate Brand Messaging and Communications Guidebook is available through the PURE Way Resource Center and offers guidance on managing negative feedback.For HUD, EPA, DRE, and other legal complaints, the Operations Manager will consult the PURE Legal Team for guidance or a local reference. Additional guidance can be found within the PURE Way Resource Center. Acceptable Forms of PaymentApplication FeesFees associated with submitting an application for a rental property must be paid online via the PMS via credit/debit card at the time of application.Move-In FeesMove-In fees may be paid via credit/debit card 5 business days prior to taking possession of the property. Additionally, move-in fees may be paid via certified check, cashier’s check, or money order. Please note that the Security Deposit, if applicable, must be paid separately from all other move-in fees.Annual FeesAny annual fees must be paid online via the PMS.Monthly FeesAny monthly fees must be paid online via the PMS.Other FeesAny other fees not defined above must be paid online via the PMS.Mold, Mildew, and Lead-Based PaintIt is PURE policy to furnish all appropriate disclosures and addendums related to Mold, Mildew, and Lead-Based Paint to the Resident based on the age and location of the property. The Resident has a responsibility to maintain the property to inhibit mold growth, and the Resident's agreement to do so is part of the Resident's material consideration in the Residential Rental Agreement. By signing the Residential Rental Agreement, Residents agree to:Maintain the premises free of dirt, debris, and moisture that can harbor moldClean any found mildew and/or mold with an appropriate cleaner designed to kill moldClean and dry any visible moisture on windows, walls, and other surfaces, including personal property, as quickly as possibleUse reasonable care to close all windows and other openings on the property to prevent water from entering the propertyUse exhaust fans, if any, in the bathroom(s) and kitchen while using those facilities and notify PURE PM of any inoperative exhaust fans promptlyImmediately notify PURE of any water intrusionImmediately notify PURE of overflows from bathroom, kitchen or laundry facilitiesImmediately notify PURE of any significant mold growth found on any surfaces on the propertyAllow PURE, with appropriate notice, to enter the property and make inspections regarding mold and ventilationRelease, indemnify, hold harmless, and forever discharge PURE PM and PURE PM's employees, agents, successors, and assigns from any and all claims, liabilities, or causes of action of any kind that the Resident, members of the Resident's household or the Resident's guests or invitees may have at any time against PURE or PURE agents resulting from the presence of mold due to the Resident's failure to comply For all properties built before 1978, it is a requirement for all PURE offices to have disclosures on file identifying the possible existence of lead in that property. The Federal LBP Brochure should be uploaded in the PMS as a global shared document, accessible to Residents and Clients.The BDR will get the Federal lead-based paint disclosure document signed by the owner of all new doors if the property or properties occurred prior to 1978; each office will retain a copy of this form to be used with all new leases moving forward.If the new door has a Resident already in place, the PM will need to ensure a copy signed by both the owner and resident is in the PMS as part of the lease packet.When a Resident’s lease is up for renewal the PM must ensure that:The Federal lead-based document signed by the owner and Resident is present in the PMSThe Resident has been provided with the EPA-published brochure “Protecting Your Family from Lead in Your Home”When a new prospective Resident is signing a lease the PM must:Make a PDF copy of the original Federal form signed by the Owner to be part of the lease packetProvide the new Resident with the EPA-published brochure “Protect Your Family from Lead in Your Home”Additional guidance is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.Resident Illness, Hospitalization, or DeathIn the event a PURE Resident experiences serious illness, hospitalization or death, the priority of all team members is to exercise professionalism and empathy in all interactions at all times.PURE does not offer an abatement of monthly fees in the event that a Resident falls ill and or is hospitalized. It is the responsibility of the Resident to provide any gap insurance that may cover accruing rent.In the event of Resident death, applicable PURE team members should activate the appropriate PURE Workflow to either modify the Residential Rental Agreement or begin the Move-Out Process.Smoke Alarms, and Carbon Monoxide DetectorsThe presence of installed smoke alarms in every home is a federal legal requirement and PURE company policy. Each office, however, is to defer to more stringent state and local requirements should they arise. At a minimum, PURE properties are required to have smoke alarms in all bedrooms and hallways on each level of the home. Smoke detectors may be installed only by members of team PURE, or by a PURE-approved Vendor.Most states, although not all, require that carbon monoxide detectors also be installed in the home. It is the responsibility of each member of team PURE to be familiar with state and local legislation impacting PURE operations.At the discretion of each office, combination smoke and carbon monoxide detectors may be purchased and installed by PURE-approved Vendors.Section 4: Applicable Laws and RegulationsTeam PURE ExpectationState and Local Level VariabilityThe Fair Housing ActThe Americans With Disabilities ActThe Servicemembers’ Civil Relief Act of 2003, SCRAThe Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair, and Painting (RRP) RuleThe Uniform Regulations of Landlord-Tenant Act, URLTAThe Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA)The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA)The CAN-SPAM ActTeam PURE ExpectationAs mentioned in Section 2, residential property management is highly regulated by a number of federal agencies, and the policies, processes, and procedures contained within the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual are designed to ensure compliance with all federal regulations.Each member of Team PURE is personally responsible for ensuring that these policies, processes, and procedures are followed. The PURE Legal team is available to assist in ensuring compliance with all regulations. Information on how to contact PURE Legal and respond to any complaints received from HUD, the EPA, the Department of Real Estate, or any other agency can be located within the PURE Way Resource Center.State and Local Level VariabilityEach state has an organization responsible for regulating and auditing the real estate activities within its jurisdiction. As such, it is acknowledged that there may be significant state and local level variability regarding residential property management rules and regulations in addition to federal regulations. Specific state and local regulations of residential property management are not described within this document. It is the responsibility of PURE team members to understand and be familiar with the state and local rules that govern property management activity within their geographic area. PURE Legal may be contacted for assistance if needed.The Fair Housing ActIt is PURE company policy that people of similar income and qualification benchmarks shouldhave the same housing opportunities available to them, regardless of personal characteristics such as race, color, religion, national origin, sex, familial status, or disability.PURE Property Management actively seeks to comply with all aspects of the Fair Housing Act by:Expecting all members of team PURE to adhere to Fair Housing Guidelines set forth by HUDProviding rigorous training on Fair Housing Guidelines on an annual basis and to all new hiresAdditional information on the Fair Housing Act, including federal and state resources, is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.The Americans With Disabilities ActPURE Property Management, as required by law, facilitates Reasonable Accommodations within the recommendations of the Americans with Disabilities Act for all persons with disabilities.Additional information on Reasonable Accommodations, including federal and state resources, is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.The Servicemembers’ Civil Relief Act of 2003, SCRAPURE Property Management acknowledges and abides by the SCRA, the federal law designed to protect service members by providing unique rights to lease termination in addition to other protective provisions.Additional information on the SCRA is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.The Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair, and Painting (RRP) RuleIn accordance with the EPA’s Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair and Painting (RRP) Rule, it is PURE company policy that a disclosure identifying the possible existence of lead-based paint be on file within the PMS for all homes constructed prior to 1978. Residents moving into a home constructed prior to 1978 must be provided with the EPA-published brochure, “Protect Your Family From Lead in Your Home.”Additional information on the Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair, and Painting (RRP) Rule is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.The Uniform Regulations of Landlord-Tenant Act, URLTAIn accordance with guidelines set forth by the URLTA, in applicable states, PURE is committed to:Compliance with applicable building and housing codes affecting health and safetyMaking all necessary repairs to put and keep premises in a fit and habitable conditionKeeping all common Residential areas in a clean and safe conditionMaintaining electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning, and other facilities and appliances in “good and safe working order and condition”Providing and maintaining appropriate receptacles for the removal of garbage and other waste, and arranging for their removalSupplying running water and reasonable amounts of hot water at all times and reasonable heat (between October 1 and May 1), except where the law does not require the building to be so equipped, or heat or hot water is generated by an installation controlled by the tenant As defined in the Tenant Obligations section of URLTA, the Resident is responsible for notifying PURE of all maintenance issues as promptly as possible. Residents are expected to submit maintenance requests through PropertyMeld. The costs of repairs are charged against the Client's reserve funds unless repairs are deemed a result of negligence or non-compliance with the Lease Agreement. States that have adopted and enforced URLTA guidelines include Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Washington.The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA)PURE Property Management is an Equal Opportunity Organization, and, as such, strives to remain in compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act for all applications or onboarding processes that utilize consumer reports. Like the Fair Housing Act, the ECOA prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, source of income, and a history of rights exercised under the Consumer Credit Protection Act.The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)During the course of normal business operations background checks, which are consumer reports, are used to make decisions regarding applicant eligibility. A consumer report may contain information such as a person’s credit characteristics, rental history, or criminal history and is protected by the Fair Credit Reporting Act.In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, PURE requests consumer reports only when permitted for normal business operations. Additionally, PURE provides a notice of adverse action following the rejection of an application or the issuance of a conditional acceptance.The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA)The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act amends the FCRA with provisions allowing consumers the right to one free credit report per year from credit reporting agencies. Consumers may also purchase, for a reasonable fee, a credit score along with information about how the credit score is calculated.The Act also adds provisions designed to prevent and mitigate identity theft, including a section that enables consumers to place fraud alerts in their credit files, as well as other enhancements to the Fair Credit Reporting Act.The CAN-SPAM ActPURE company policy dictates adherence to a high standard of professionalism, accuracy, and confidentiality in communications with Residents, Clients, and Vendors. In accordance with the CAN-SPAM Act, PURE strives to uphold a standard of truthful, fair, and appropriate communication in all areas of business.Section 5: Standard Operating ProceduresNew Client Acquisition and OnboardingManaging PURE ClientsCentralized LeasingCentralized Leasing: Residential ApplicationsApplication Communication GuidelinesResidential Listing InquiriesResident Move InProperty MaintenanceAfter-Hours Maintenance Call FlowEmergency Weather ResponseProperty ManagementResident Move OutNew Client Acquisition and OnboardingNew Client AcquisitionBenchmarking a PropertyNegotiating the Property Management AgreementDocumentation and FormsClient InsuranceClient Reserve AccountsStoring and Reviewing Client DocumentationNew Investor Client OnboardingNew Property OnboardingNew Client AcquisitionA “Client” is defined as a property investor or owner with one or more properties who wishes to hire PURE to manage their assets. When an inquiry or lead for property management services comes to any member of team PURE, that team member should collect the following:Potential Client’s full namePotential Client’s phone numberPotential Client’s email addressCity, state, and zip code of prospective new doorsQuestions from the potential Client should be recorded and directed to the PURE Business Development team along with the potential Client’s contact information and property details. The Business Development Representative (BDR) is responsible for Property Management Agreement negotiations, property benchmarking, and closing.All information regarding the lead may be directed to the PURE Business Development team via Slack on the #ask-business-development channel. Information should be shared using the template below.New BDR OpportunityPotential Client’s full namePotential Client’s phone numberPotential Client’s email addressCity, state, and zip code of prospective new doorsBenchmarking a PropertyThe BDR will analyze the financial characteristics of, or “benchmark,” for all potential properties to see how they compare to similar properties in the same market. To be approved for inclusion on the PURE platform, potential properties must meet the following benchmarking criteria:The property must rent for at least 85% of the average rent in the local market.There may not be any trailers on the property, regardless of permanent foundation.The property may not be furnished - PURE does not take the inventory.There may not be any personal inventory left behind from the Client.There may not be a Client and/or one of their family members living on the property.The property must be located within 50 miles of the management office.The property may not have any shared living spaces.The property may not have any HUD/Section 8/State Voucher Residents unless required by state law.The property may not have a Client who interferes with the management of their asset.The property may not have any Client controlled cameras.The property may only use PURE documents and PURE-approved Vendors for the duration of the property management agreement.The property cannot have a trampoline. If it does, it must be removed prior to rental.If the property has a swimming pool, the Client is responsible for all costs associated with maintenance and repair.If the property is Resident Occupied, proof of good standing/Rent Payment History is required Review Residential Rental Agreements of all resident-occupied properties being considered.If the result of the benchmarking exercise determines that the property is not eligible for inclusion on the PURE platform, then the BDR will connect with the potential Client to recommend corrective action and halt the acquisition process until the time that corrective action is taken.If the result of the benchmarking exercise determines the property is eligible for inclusion on the PURE platform, then the BDR will contact the Client to facilitate an on-site evaluation of the potential property or properties.Negotiating the Property Management AgreementThe Property Management Agreement (PMA) is the legal contract that governs the terms of the relationship between PURE and the Client.The standard 12-month PURE PMA is used as a baseline contract for all potential Clients and contains specific language that outlines how changes in terms are managed. Some clauses may be negotiated by the BDR within allowable parameters; for example, the BDR has the discretion outlined below to negotiate the terms of all fees and offer discounts depending on specific circumstances of the potential Client’s portfolio:On an individual single-family home, PURE’s standard management fee is 10% of the monthly rent; however, when a Client brings 3 or more doors to the PURE platform, it is permissible for the BDR to negotiate the management fee to no less than 8%.The management fee is earned in full at the beginning of the agreement; however, provisions exist that allow it to be billed and paid monthly.○ If/when the Client chooses to terminate the PMA the management fee due accelerates. The PURE PMA contains language outlining management fee acceleration upon Client termination.Additional fees apply as defined in the PURE PMA. These include:Client start-up fees, intended to cover the cost of welcoming a new ClientLeasing fees, enacted when PURE negotiates a new Residential Rental AgreementAdditional fees as defined and enacted by PUREBefore the execution of the PMA, all fees billable to the Client must be disclosed and acknowledged.Documentation and FormsThe Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to complete the Client Onboarding Package (COP) once the PMA has been signed and executed. The Client Onboarding Package (COP) encompasses the following:Client Intake Form, completed by a new Client to provide full and complete information as a part of the PURE Client Onboarding processPURE Client Direct Deposit Form, giving PURE permission to electronically debit or credit money from a Client’s bank, credit union, or prepaid card account when payment is dueInsurance Authorization, a copy of the Client’s Insurance policy authorizing PURE Property Management as an added insured party where permitted by state or local lawHOA/COA documents, if applicableUtility Authorization Form, authorizing team PURE to manage utility transfers on behalf of the ClientClient Self-Access Authorization Form, permitting PURE to expand visibility and accessibility of the vacant rental property by allowing for self-showingsAll documents must be signed and dated in the correct locations, and loaded with the Client and property into the PMS. Responsiveness to the Client is critical during Client Onboarding and is the responsibility of all PURE team members associated with the process.Client InsuranceCoverage thresholds are defined within the PMA, and PURE Clients are required to carry insurance appropriate to the size and value of their portfolio. Clients must provide a copy of their insurance policy. Where applicable by law, PURE should be listed by the Client on their policy as an additional insured party.Client Reserve AccountsPURE Clients are required to establish and fund a “reserve” account to fund property emergencies, minor maintenance requests, and on-site repairs. This reserve may also be used in cases where the Client is non-responsive to PURE communications. The reserve account must be established before the completion of onboarding, and funded with a minimum amount of $500 per door. If necessary, the account may be partially or fully funded with the proceeds of a Resident’s first-month rent.Storing and Reviewing Client DocumentationThe Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to create a new folder in the office’s dedicated Google Drive titled with the Client’s name. All documentation will be added to this Google Drive, and the Client’s tax ID will be verified using IRS Taxpayer Identification Matching (TIN) Tools. Once the Client’s tax ID has been verified, the Senior Property Manager will collaborate with their Pod members to create a new Client Profile and portal within the PMS. FlowEnd Management FlowThe Senior Property Manager is the main point of contact for any day-to-day operations that require the approval or notification of the Client. The Senior Property Manager handles all Client correspondence, including PMA Renewals, Client Contributions, and any other matters that pertain to the Client’s portfolio. If the Senior Property Manager is unavailable and there is an immediate need, then the Operations Manager is the next point of contact. The Senior Property Manager begins their relationship with the Client following the execution of the initial PMA. The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to onboard the Client and will collaborate with their Pod to enter the portfolio into the PURE platform and begin management operations for the property or properties. Completion of the PURE Vendor Onboarding Process is required for any Client-preferred Vendors. The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the Maintenance team to onboard new Vendors. During the relationship between PURE Property Management and the Client, the Residents should have no direct contact with the Client.Property Needs AssessmentFollowing Client and Property Onboarding within the Property Management System, the Senior Property Manager will collaborate with their Pod members and Centralized Maintenance to assess the new Client’s property holdings and needs.If|ThenThe new property is currently Resident-occupied,|Contact the Resident to schedule a Property Evaluation.The new property is currently Resident-occupied, ANDThe Resident is planning to move out,|Contact the Resident to schedule an initial Property Evaluation.Follow procedures for Resident Move-Out, Vacancy Management, and Marketing a Property for Rent.The new property is not currently Resident-occupied,|Contact the Client to schedule a Rent Ready Evaluation of the Property.Circumstances may arise under which the Client still lives in the home at the time of joining the PURE platform; in this circumstance, there must be a clear timeline for the Client to vacate the property and allow for any updates required to make the property rent-ready for a new Resident.In addition to the above circumstances, the Client may be uncertain about whether they want to rent or sell their property. In such a scenario, it is permissible to simultaneously list a property for both sale and rent under the following conditions:PURE is the listing agent for the salePURE is the property management company of record for the propertyIf both of these conditions are not met, a simultaneous listing is not acceptable. If the property is already occupied the Resident is not required to complete a new Residential Rental Agreement on the PURE platform until their lease renewal date, unless there is a violation or non-compliance with state or local law. PURE does not currently charge an additional fee to manage existing non-conforming leases.If the occupying Resident has an existing month-to-month Residential Rental Agreement, the occupying Resident must complete the application process via the PURE platform to convert to a 12-month lease immediately, barring extenuating circumstances.Client approval must be obtained if there is an extenuating circumstance necessitating the creation of a lease term outside of the standard 12-month PURE lease.If the new property is currently Resident occupied, the Property Manager will review new Resident information and enter all applicable data into the PMS, including:lease documentsapplication documentsevaluation reportsphotos/videossecurity depositpet/animal information, if applicableClient ConnectionThe Property Management team is responsible for maintaining the relationship with the Investor Client. Use Client Connection Calls for guidance to manage your PURE-Client relationship. Client Termination FlowIf, during the term of the lease, a Client chooses to sell or move into a property or terminate the Residential Rental Agreement for any other reason within legal limits, PURE will follow the Residential Rental Agreement and Property Management Agreement until the property is either closed out or onboarded with a new Client.Collect Management FeesBefore the termination date, collect all management fee balances due under the terms of the Property Management Agreement. As a best practice, they should be collected from either the Resident’s rent received or the Client’s reserve account.Transfer the Security DepositWhile the property is still Resident-occupied, the PM Pod will transfer the security deposit back to the Client by creating a check that is made out to the Client.The PM Pod will notify the Resident(s) that the security deposit for that property has been transferred to the Client.If the Resident is enrolled in the Security Deposit Replacement Program (SDRP) there is no security deposit to return. Instead, provide the Client with the appropriate termination form to re-disclose what is ending.Terminate Maintenance ServicesThe Client must be informed that, after the termination date, PURE can no longer coordinate maintenance for their property; any maintenance in progress at the time of termination must be handed off to the Client.Documents Client Termination ReasonsFor internal tracking purposes, the Senior PM will capture the Client’s reason(s) for terminating the PMA. Generally, the reasons should be grouped into one of three categories:Good ChurnNeutral ChurnBad ChurnThe reason for churn will be tracked by PURE to obtain key management insights that can be used to provide feedback to teams or update processes and procedures.“Good churn” offers additional benefits from the transaction, for example:A Client terminates the PMA because they have sold the property and PURE has brokered the saleA Client terminates the PMA because they have sold the property and the new Client of that property signs a new PMA with PURE“Neutral churn” occurs when:The Client chooses to move back into their propertyThe Client sells the home, but PURE does not broker the saleThe Client sells the home, but PURE does not retain the new ClientThere are several “bad” churn scenarios that could potentially be captured:The Client is not satisfied with PURE’s serviceThe Client has decided to self-manage the propertyThe Client has hired a new Property Manager that offers some level of differentiation from PUREPURE initiates the termination of the relationship due to non-performance by the ClientRegardless of their rationale for leaving the PURE platform, the Operations Manager will reach out to the terminating Client to facilitate the exit survey, obtain feedback, and express PURE’s gratitude for the business relationship.The Senior Property Manager will ensure a smooth transition during Client Termination.End Management FlowGeneral InformationThe End Management Flow begins when a Property Management Agreement or Service Agreement is Manager notifies ShowMojo (or other self-access vendor) to release the lock, if applicable.This process is complete.Centralized LeasingGeneral InformationLead InquiryApplicant ScreeningGeneral InformationPURE Centralized Leasing helps to maintain consistency and communication across all areas of the leasing process and ensures that all Residential Rental Applications are managed in accordance with PURE policies in the order that they are received and completed.The Leasing Specialist fields all inquiries and communicates with all leads for each property listing, and is responsible for documenting these interactions in Tenant Turner, ShowMojo, and the applicable PMS.Lead InquiryWhen a lead inquires about a property that they located on a listing site - e.g., Zillow - they are invited via an automated message to answer pre-qualification questions presented in accordance with PURE guidelines, and, if they are pre-qualified, to schedule an appointment for a self-showing of the property. Leads who do not pre-qualify are automatically notified that they are ineligible to move forward with scheduling a self-showing.Pre-qualified leads, after scheduling the appointment, are alerted through both email and text message notifications in addition to receiving a calendar invitation; notifications will include all details regarding the appointment's date, time, and the property's address. Leads are authorized and able to access the property for a self-showing only at the time of their scheduled appointment with a time-sensitive unique SentriLock electronic lockbox code. As with other calls, when a lead calls any PURE office they are directed through the interactive voice response system (IVR) menu of options. Leads will select the Leasing option from the IVR menu, and, should they request to speak with a representative, are forwarded to the Leasing team for assistance. The Leasing team may also communicate with leads via email, using the assigned office email address for Leasing.Applicant ScreeningAll applicants are screened utilizing VeriFast and TransUnion to verify identity, income, employment, credit eligibility, criminal, bankruptcy, non-sufficient funds transactions, and eviction records. Self-employed applicants may also access these options by providing tax documentation and by connecting their bank account to VeriFast. Additional rental eligibility requirements apply to self-employed applicants.All applicants, regardless of whether or not they have a pet or assistance animal, are required to complete a PetScreening profile to comply with PURE company policies. If the applicant cannot do this, they may upload their last 3 bank statements. Access to multiple bank accounts is permitted.○ Log in to their payroll account online. When an applicant does not have an online payroll account, they may upload their last 2 pay stubs. Pay stubs must be in PDF format and not in a picture format. (VeriFast is unable to extract metadata from an image.)○ Self-employed applicants will be required to upload their most recent tax return in place of pay stubs.VeriFast Screening Instructions1. ID Verification: This will say Verified or Unverified. (Unverified is a detection of fraud.)b. Verify that the rental rate provided is accurate. If it is not, click Edit and enter the correct amount.c. Income to Rent Requirement: An applicant’s combined income must meet the income requirement as set forth in the screening criteria. There are 6 VeriFast accounts for OR.a. Portland, OR-Financially Responsible: Income requirement is 2.5x.*b. Non-Financially Responsible: Only verifies identity.c. OR-Financially Responsible: Income requirement for applicant and guarantor is 3x.d. Self-employed Portland: Income requirement is *2.5x or 6x avg bank balance.e. OR Self-employed: Income requirement is 3x or 6x avg bank balance.iii. 🛑 Portland, OR: *The income requirement varies between 2x - 2.5x for an applicant(s) based on the rental rate. Janet Cantolan 831-454-9455 Ext 217, leasing.specialist@hacosantacruz.org, www.hacosantacruz.orge. Determining whether the applicant meets the income requirement varies by jurisdiction.i. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. This law prohibits a landlord, in instances where there is a government rent subsidy (e.g., Section 8 voucher) from using a person’s credit history as part of the rental application process without offering the applicant the option, at the applicant’s discretion, of providing lawful, verifiable alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay the portion of the rent to be paid by the tenant, including but not limited to, government benefit payments, pay records, and bank statements. If applicant elects to provide alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay, the landlord must provide the applicant reasonable time to respond with that alternative evidence and reasonably consider that alternative evidence in lieu of the person’s credit history in determining whether to offer the rental accommodation to the applicant. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the landlord may still request information or documentation to verify employment, to request landlord references, and to verify the identity of the applicant.North Bay, CA (Multi-Family Homes)1.
