Enjoy the rest of your day.”PMS Task Steps - Residential ApplicationsResident Move-InResident Move-InResident Move-InOnce the Leasing process has been completed, the Resident is ready to take possession of the leased premises. As the Resident takes possession, they conduct a move-in evaluation to ensure that there is agreement between the Resident and the Property Manager regarding the condition of the property prior to occupancy.While there may be some variability in state-specific laws regarding the move-in evaluation, the general PURE policy is that the future Resident has 3 days from the date of possession to submit their evaluation. The Resident will complete this evaluation using the zTenant App unless state laws require the use of a specific form. Move-In EvaluationStep 1: The Property Manager Initiates the zInspector Move-In Evaluation RequestStep 2: The Resident Responds to the zInspector Move-In Evaluation RequestIf|ThenThe Resident does not submit the Move-In Evaluation within the 3 business days of occupancy,ORThe Resident submits a satisfactory Move-In Evaluation within three (3) business days of occupancy,|The move-in evaluation workflow is complete.The Resident submits an unacceptable Move-In Evaluation within the 3 business days of occupancy due to any incident that has occurred between the last on-site visit and the date of the evaluation,|The Property Manager will facilitate the submission of a work order via PropertyMeld.Property Maintenance MaintenanceService Request GuidelinesManaging Resident Lock-outsManaging Maintenance RequestsMaintenance Work OrdersCanceling a MeldRoutine Property EvaluationsMaintenancePURE Centralized Maintenance helps to maintain consistency and communication across all aspects of both routine maintenance and major repairs on Client-owned properties and helps to ensure that all maintenance requests are managed with the utmost professionalism in accordance with PURE policies.The Centralized Maintenance team’s response to a maintenance request is dependent upon three factors: urgency, the timing of the request, and the estimated cost. For non-emergency maintenance requests received during normal business hours (9 AM - 4 PM), the Maintenance Coordinator is required to respond to the request on the same business day with an estimated timeline for resolution of the submitted maintenance request. For non-emergency maintenance requests received outside of normal business hours, the Maintenance Coordinator is required to respond to the request with an estimated timeline for resolution of the submitted maintenance request by the end of the following business day. If the maintenance request is an emergency, PURE’s target response time is within 30 minutes. Emergency maintenance requests are received and managed by the Maintenance Coordinator during normal business hours. Outside of normal business hours, emergency maintenance requests are received and managed by the After Hours Maintenance Service team.All maintenance requests must be submitted via PropertyMeld. Residents are expected to submit their own non-emergency maintenance requests into PropertyMeld via their Resident Portal. Residents who are not in need of reasonable accommodation due to a disability, but who insist that their non-emergency maintenance requests be accepted by phone, text or email, will be charged an administrative fee where allowable by law.Service Request Guidelines The below table outlines the priority, response timeline, and completion timeline of each service type and category. Service Request GuidelinesManaging Resident Lock-outsThe PURE response to Resident lock-outs is dependent on two factors: the timing of the lock-out, and the physical location of the PURE office.During Normal Business HoursIf|ThenThe PURE office has a copy of the property key on-hand,|The Resident may “check out” the Office’s copy of the key from the PURE office during normal business hours in order to have a new copy made. The “checked out” key must be returned by the Resident to the office location.The PURE office does not have a copy of the property key on handORThe PURE office is a virtual location,|The PM will coordinate with the Pod, using discretion to determine whether it is more appropriate for the PM to obtain a key and meet the Resident at the property OR for the Resident to follow the After Hours workflow.After Business HoursIf a Resident is locked out after normal business hours, it is their responsibility to call a locksmith.If|ThenThe Locksmith is able to unlock the lockANDthere is a physical office location to replace a lost key,|The Resident may “check out” the Office’s copy of the key from the PURE office during normal business hours in order to have a new copy made. The “checked out” key must be returned by the Resident to the office location.The Locksmith is unable to unlock the lockANDthere are no additional copies of the key available,|The Resident assumes responsibility for all associated costs of rekeying the lock(s). A copy of the new key must be delivered by the Resident to the office location, if applicable, during normal business hours. Managing Maintenance RequestsAs previously stated, Residents are expected to submit their own non-emergency maintenance requests to PropertyMeld via their Resident Portal. For maintenance requests that are considered to be an emergency under the PURE Service Request Guidelines, the Maintenance team will assist the Resident at no additional fee. Residents who are not experiencing an emergency and who are not in need of reasonable accommodation due to a disability, but who insist that their non-emergency maintenance requests be accepted by phone, text or email, will be charged an administrative fee where allowable by law.When applicable, the Maintenance Coordinator or After Hours Maintenance Services Representative may assist the Resident by guiding them through troubleshooting steps prior to the submission of a maintenance request or prior to the creation of a work order. Troubleshooting may help resolve the issue more quickly and more efficiently and may help Residents avoid additional charges. Troubleshooting also assists PURE in determining which party, the Resident or the Client, is responsible for the cost of repairs. During the troubleshooting process, Maintenance team members are able to investigate the issue and gather all relevant information as to the perceived cause of the issue, the frequency of the issue, and the timing of the issue.In the event that the Maintenance team member is unable to successfully coach the Resident toward a resolution as part of the troubleshooting process, a maintenance work order will be created and an expert tradesperson will be dispatched to investigate the issue. Services rendered that are not included within the scope of the executed Residential Rental Agreement or that are in excess of the approved work order authorization amount are considered to be the financial responsibility of the Resident.Duplicate Maintenance RequestsThe Maintenance team holds Vendors accountable for quality workmanship, as PURE has an obligation to facilitate maintenance services in the best interests of Clients. If a duplicate maintenance request is received for a recurring maintenance issue within 12 months of dispatch, the same Vendor who serviced the original work order will be dispatched once more.Estimating the Cost of RepairsWhen Clients sign the PURE PMA, they agree to a $500 maintenance spending limit. The maintenance spending limit is the amount that PURE is authorized to spend prior to requesting the Client’s approval for completing a repair. There are exceptions to the spending limit: for example, if a building has had repair work completed every month, PURE is obligated to notify Clients of all upcoming repairs and obtain approval, even if the estimates are smaller than the maintenance spend limit.PURE has an obligation to facilitate maintenance requests in the best interests of Clients. The Maintenance team holds Vendors accountable for quality workmanship at a reasonable cost by obtaining multiple estimates prior to dispatching a work order. Each estimate obtained outlines the cost and scope of work, and Vendors must meet all PURE Vendor requirements in order to submit their bid. To be considered, the estimate received must fall within the reasonable market range for completion of the repair. During the bid process, the Maintenance Coordinator tags the Meld as “Waiting for an Estimate.”PURE demonstrates a commitment to due diligence on behalf of the Client by researching the home’s warranty status, obtaining multiple estimates, outlining efforts to troubleshoot and resolve the issue, and by identifying the root cause of the needed repair in order to determine whether the Resident may be financially responsible for the cost of completion. Requesting Client Contribution and ApprovalShould the estimated cost of completing repairs exceed the $500 maintenance spending limit, the Maintenance Coordinator will collaborate with the Senior Property Manager to facilitate the request for Client approval and Client contribution to cover costs in excess of the $500 limit.Client Contribution RequestsStep 1: The Maintenance Coordinator Contacts the Client and Senior Property ManagerThe Maintenance Coordinator will provide the estimate(s) with detailed notes and photos describing the scope of work and repair costs to the Client and Senior Property Manager.This communication should outline the:Primary issue(s) noted in the maintenance request, for example: “The electric water heater is no longer producing hot water.”Diagnosis of the issue, for example: “The Vendor has shared with us that the cause of this issue is the heating element in the unit, which has unfortunately failed.”Solution for the issue, for example: “This model of electric water heater does not allow for the removal and replacement of the failed heating element, meaning that replacing the heating element is not an option. The best solution for this issue is the replacement of the unit entirely.”Cost to resolve the issue, for example: “Based on the range of estimates received and our current market analysis, replacing this unit will cost between $800 and $2,000.”Timeline for the repair, for example: “The estimated timeline for completion of this repair is 5 to 7 days.”This communication should close with a time-sensitive call to action for the Client, with a clear request for approval and financial contribution, for example:“Please respond to this message with your approval and make all applicable financial  ontributions within 24 hours so that this work order may be dispatched. If you do not respond within 24 hours, your approval is assumed and we will proceed with completing the repair.”Step 2: The Maintenance Coordinator Tags the MeldThe Maintenance Coordinator tags the Meld with both “Waiting for Estimate/Approval” and “PM Review.”Step 3: The Senior Property Manager Places a Hold on the Client Reserve AccountWithin the PMS, the Senior Property Manager will place a hold on the Client’s reserve account to ensure that no distributions are made prior to the completion and invoicing of the maintenance request.Client ApprovalIf|Then The Client does not respond within 24 hours |The Maintenance Coordinator calls the Client to follow up on the message.The Client does not respond after more than 24 hours,|The Maintenance Coordinator contacts the Senior Property Manager to escalate the request. The Senior Property Manager contacts the Client to obtain approval and initiate contribution funding.The Client requests an additional or alternate estimate,|The Maintenance Coordinator immediately  dispatches an estimate request in PropertyMeld.The Client requests a specific Vendor to be used,|The Maintenance Coordinator verifies that the Vendor is a PURE-approved Vendor.For Vendors who are not yet PURE-approved, the Maintenance team begins the Vendor Onboarding Process. Once all Vendor Onboarding requirements have been met, the Maintenance Coordinator will send a request to the Vendor for a bid.The Client denies the service request,|The Senior Property Manager, at their discretion, either directs the Maintenance Coordinator to cancel the Meld or to proceed with the Service Request without Client approval. If the Senior PM proceeds without Client approval:1. Verify that funding in the Client reserve account will cover the cost of repairs.2. Provide direction to the Maintenance Coordinator on the completion of repairs based on the availability of funds held or received from rental income or Client contribution.The Client approves the service request, |The Maintenance Coordinator creates a note within PropertyMeld stating that the Client approved, including the Client’s name, approval date, and approved budget.Maintenance Work OrdersThe Maintenance team maintains and updates all maintenance requests and work orders. Work orders are created and dispatched following the Client’s approval and contribution, or at the discretion of the Senior Property Manager when a repair request can not be refused or delayed.Step 1: The Work Order is DispatchedThe Maintenance Coordinator will notify the selected Vendor that approval for completion of the repair(s) has been granted, and that services can be scheduled. The Vendor should take and submit “before” photos as the project begins.Step 2: Repair Work BeginsThe Maintenance Coordinator will remain in communication with the PM Pod, the Client, the Resident, and the Vendor(s) for the duration of work. Milestones, completion dates, and correspondence will be managed and maintained by the Maintenance Coordinator.Step 3: The Work Order is CompletedThe Vendor, once all services have been completed, should enter work completion notes in PropertyMeld as well as take and submit “after” photos of all completed work. Following the submission of photos and work completion notes, the Vendor may also submit their invoice under the PURE Vendor Invoicing Policy.Step 4: The Work Order Invoice is ProcessedThe Maintenance Coordinator reviews the invoice with work completion notes to ensure that all work was completed satisfactorily and that the invoice matches the service request estimate.The Maintenance Coordinator transfers any warranty details or other pertinent information from the completed Meld and invoice to the Property Management System and enters any applicable markup charges.Step 5: The Maintenance Coordinator Approves the InvoiceThe Maintenance Coordinator, after reviewing the invoice and ensuring that work has been completed satisfactorily, will approve the invoice payment. The invoice and photos of the completed work will be shared with the Client and Senior Property Manager; additionally, the Maintenance Coordinator will notify the Staff Accountant of invoice approval. The Senior PM will remove the hold on Client funds when the invoice is approved for payment.Canceling a MeldIn certain circumstances, it may be necessary to cancel a Meld. Circumstances might include duplicate requests, or the refusal of the Client to respond to a service request that is not categorized as an “Essential Service” or a source of liability. Cancellation of a Meld may only be completed at the discretion of the Senior PM or the Operations Manager. In the event that a Meld is canceled, the Senior Property Manager will notify the Client of the cancellation via email.Routine Property EvaluationsProperty evaluations facilitated by the Property Manager are required at the beginning and end of every lease in every property and may be required for other reasons throughout the duration of the Resident’s tenancy. Property evaluations ensure that Residents are actively participating in the stewardship of the property, and allow issues to be identified and addressed in a timely manner.Property EvaluationsStep 1: A Property Evaluation is IndicatedIf|ThenThe property is Resident-occupied, |The Property Manager will...1. Contact the Resident to notify them and schedule the evaluation. 2. Notify the Field Technician of the need for an evaluation.The property is vacant,|The Property Manager will...1. Notify the Field Technician of the need for an evaluation.Step 2: An Evaluation Meld is CreatedThe Field Technician will create the Evaluation Meld, and will schedule the property evaluation based upon information provided by the Property Manager.Step 3: The Evaluation Reminder is SentThe Field Technician will coordinate with the PM 72 hours prior to the scheduled property evaluation to remind the Resident of their upcoming scheduled evaluation.If|ThenThe Resident confirms the scheduled evaluation or does not respond,|The Field Technician will proceed to initiate the evaluation at the scheduled time.The Resident requests to reschedule the evaluation,|The Field Technician will coordinate with the PM to reschedule the evaluation via PropertyMeld.Step 4: The Field Technician Conducts the Property EvaluationThe Field Technician will proceed with the evaluation on the scheduled date at the scheduled time. If the Resident is unable to provide access to the home on the scheduled date at the scheduled time, the Field Technician will coordinate with the PM to reschedule and to add a charge to the Resident’s ledger for the missed appointment.During the property evaluation, the Field Technician will use the zInspector App to:1. Capture photos of the exterior of the home, including:a. The front yardb. The backyardc. The side yardd. Landscapinge. Exterior light fixturesf. Sidingg. Porches, patios, and decksh. Fencingi. Outdoor storage areas2. Capture photos of the interior of the home, including:a. All roomsb. Light fixturesc. Appliancesd. Under sinkse. Wallsf. Ceilingsg. Flooring3. Capture photos of any apparent damage to the home. Details should be provided along with photos of any apparent damage requiring repair or replacement.If|ThenThe Field Technician encounters minor maintenance needs requiring no supplies to complete during an evaluation,ORThe Field Technician encounters minor maintenance tasks,ANDThe Field Technician has the required supplies,ANDThe cost of the repair will be under the $500 spending threshold,|The Field Technician may, at their discretion, assess and resolve the need. Details of this resolution must be documented within the property evaluation notes, including the:Scope of workBefore and after photosSupplies usedTime spentThe Field Technician encounters the need for a repair in the “Essential Service” service request category,|The Field Technician will...1. Document the need for repair with photos, and an indication as to whether the repairs might be completed by a Field Technician or the repairs require Vendor estimates.2. Enter a new Maintenance Service Request in PropertyMeld.3. Notify the Property Manager.The Field Technician encounters the need for a repair in the “High Priority” service request category,|The Field Technician will...1. Document the need for repair with photos, and an indication as to whether the repairs might be completed by a Field Technician or the repairs require Vendor estimates.2. Enter a new Maintenance Service Request in PropertyMeld.3. Notify the Property Manager.Step 5: The Field Technician Submits the Property EvaluationThe Field Technician will proceed with their submission of photos and commentary into the zInspector app and PropertyMeld. Following submission, the Field Technician will advise the PM Pod of any recommendations or required repairs.Step 6: The Senior Property Manager Notifies the ClientOnce the evaluation report has been received from the Field Technician, the Senior PM will notify the Client that the property evaluation has been completed, and advise of any recommendations or required repairs.Step 7: The Work Order Invoice is ProcessedThe Maintenance Coordinator reviews the invoice with work completion notes to ensure that all work was completed satisfactorily and that the invoice is in alignment with PURE policies. The Maintenance Coordinator transfers any pertinent information from the completed Meld and invoice to the Property Management System and enters any applicable markup charges.After Hours Maintenance Service PURE Way Call Flow General ResponsibilitiesCall GreetingsAuthentication and IdentificationIdentifying the IssueAuthentication of Resident ProfileTroubleshoot the IssueNext StepsCall EscalationGeneral ResponsibilitiesAt the beginning of each shift, review all open “After Hours Emergency” Melds. Document the “time of call” for any calls made to emergency response services.Emergency Weather ResponseCentralized Maintenance Department (CMD) Emergency WeatherStorm Damage EmailStorm Damage Meld TagStorm Affecting CMD Emergency Weather Response TeamStorm Affecting After-Hours Call CenterStorm Tracking and SurveillanceCentralized Maintenance Department (CMD) Emergency WeatherIn the event of a potential natural disaster or extreme inclement weather within the continental United States, the Centralized Maintenance Department (CMD) Emergency Weather Response Team performs the duties detailed in this procedure.A Natural disaster or extreme inclement weather can be defined as:EarthquakeTornadoHurricaneWildfireExtreme cold/ winter eventThe Emergency Weather Response team includes:Regional Maintenance Team LeadersDirector of MaintenanceCMD Project CoordinatorThey oversee the storm damage email and After Hours Emergency Maintenance Line during regular business hours during and after an emergency weather event. If an Emergency Weather Response Team Member cannot work safely or loses internet access due to the storm, they are not expected to perform these duties until they are safe.Storm Damage EmailWhen a storm occurs Residents are advised by the office's Operations Manager(s) to relay any storm-related damage to the storm.damage@purepm.co and include their appropriate maintenance platform when possible. If damage is reported to storm.damage@purepm.co an automated response asks Residents for important information such as PURE Office Name, property address, and Resident name and phone number. Once this information is collected, our on-call Emergency Weather Response team will determine the best course of action by inputting a Meld/Service Request or assigning a vendor. The Emergency Weather Response Team Member responds to the Resident advising of the next steps. This email includes the Maintenance Coordinator and Operations Manager if the Emergency Weather Response team determines this is necessary.The inbox at storm.damage@purepm.co is checked every hour by members of the Emergency Weather Response team for 7 days after the end of the storm event to monitor for any further reports of damage.Storm Damage Meld TagWhen storm damage is reported through PropertyMeld, a tag with the name of the storm event and year is made (i.e., Hurricane Carlos 2023/Ice Storm 2023). This tag provides tracking for specific emergency weather events and the related workload/damage.Storm Affecting CMD Emergency Weather Response TeamAn Emergency Weather Response Team Member residing in an area impacted by a storm is expected to take necessary precautions and only work if they are safe.  Additional assistance could be required from the After-Hours Maintenance Service Call Center or Maintenance Coordinators to supplement storm-affected team members. Offices affected by the event will also have team members on standby who may need to assist.Storm Affecting After-Hours Call CenterThe CMD Emergency Weather Response Team may assist with calls until the After-Hours Maintenance Service Team Members are safe to return to their regular duties if an emergency weather event affects our after-hours call center.Storm Tracking and SurveillanceEmergency Weather Response Team Members use WeatherUnderground to track extreme weather conditions throughout the US to maintain a good knowledge of potential weather conditions that will cause maintenance issues. Alerts are shared among the Emergency Weather Response Team Members and leadership so the Emergency Weather Response team is actively aware of events that may require their attention.Property The Property Manager will receive a Resident Delinquency Report via the PMS to assist in tracking delinquencies. All notices must be posted in compliance with state and local laws.Send Late Rent Letter and Notification of Late FeeOn the 6th of the month or on the next available business day, the Property Manager will issue the Resident a Late Rent Letter in the PMS to notify the Resident that a late fee has been automatically applied to their ledger in the amount of 5% of their total rent, and that payment of their late rent is due immediately.If|ThenThe Property Manager is able to make contact with the Resident regarding late rent|The Property Manager will note on the office’s Delinquent Resident Report that the Resident has made a promise to pay, including a deadline and method of payment.The Property Manager is unable to make contact with the Resident regarding late rent by the 10th of the month or the earliest possible,|The Property Manager will begin the eviction process in accordance with state and local laws.Non-Sufficient FundsIn the event that a method of payment is returned or not cleared, Residents are charged the maximum NSF Fee allowed by state law, as detailed in the signed Residential Rental Agreement, for each NSF event that impacts PURE. If multiple fees are collected as a single payment and incur one NSF event, this is considered as one single event and not separate NSFs. NSF events are counted per 12 months starting from the first NSF event.Following the Resident’s first NSF event, an NSF fee shall be applied to the Resident’s account. The Resident must make their next payment with certified funds. No subsequent payments will be required to be in certified funds.Following the Resident’s second event, an NSF fee shall be applied to the Resident’s account. The Resident must make their next payment with certified funds, and shall be required to make payments via certified funds for 90 days. The requirement for certified funds can be removed after 90 days upon the Resident’s request. If any other NSFs occur, a new 90-day period requirement of certified funds will begin from the last NSF occurrence.If|ThenThe Resident experiences their first NSF event,|An NSF fee shall be applied to the Resident’s account. The ADA is a civil rights law that prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in all areas of public life, including jobs, schools, transportation, and all public and private places that are open to the general public. The Act also requires the provision of "risk-based-pricing" notices and credit scores to consumers in connection with denials or less favorable offers of credit. The Act also adds provisions designed to prevent and mitigate identity theft, including a section that enables consumers to place fraud alerts in their credit files, as well as other enhancements to the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Certain provisions related to data security ("red flags" of possible identity theft) were amended by the Red Flag Program Clarification Act of 2010, Pub. L. 111-319, 124 Stat. 3457, to clarify and narrow the meaning of "creditor" for purposes of those provisions.The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)Protects information collected by consumer reporting agencies such as credit bureaus, medical information companies, and tenant screening services. Information in a consumer report cannot be provided to anyone who does not have a purpose specified in the Act.The Servicemembers’ Civil Relief Act of 2003, SCRAA federal law designed to protect service members by providing unique rights to lease termination in addition to other protective provisions.The Servicemembers' Civil Relief Act (SCRA) postpones or suspends certain civil obligations to enable service members to devote their full attention to duty and relieve stress on their families. The SCRA covers all active duty service members, reservists, and members of the National Guard while on active duty.The Uniform Regulations of Landlord-Tenant Act, URLTAA law governing residential landlord and tenant rental agreements entered into or renewed after July 1, 1975. Comply with all obligations primarily imposed upon tenants by applicable building and housing codes; · keep the tenant's premises “as clean and safe as the condition of the premises permit”; · dispose of garbage, rubbish and other wastes from the dwelling unit “in a clean and safe ... States that have adopted and enforced URLTA guidelines include Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Washington.TurnoverThe act of one tenant moving out of a property, evaluating the property then preparing it for the next tenant, and marketing with new rent rate.Type of Action Action types are User/platform or System.Unauthorized AnimalsAn animal that is not registered on a resident's PetScreening.com Profile, and has not been disclosed to the Property Manager. Unauthorized animals discovered on a property are considered a lease violation, and where permitted by law, can be grounds to begin the eviction process. If a Resident fails to disclose an animal at any point during the term of the Residential Rental Agreement, at the Operations Manager’s discretion the Resident may be allowed to complete the animal screening process to certify any unauthorized animal.The Uniform Regulations of Landlord-Tenant Act, URLTAA law governing residential landlord and tenant rental agreements entered into or renewed after July 1, 1975.Unit (AKA Door)A single property unit (123 Willow Unit #2A). Section 1: PURE Way Playbook Overview 

Introduction

PURE Way Playbook Change Request Form

Introduction

PURE Property Management’s vision is to make the joy of renting a home PURE and to provide a simple and satisfying experience for all. To support this vision, the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual outlines the policies, processes, and procedures that drive every aspect of the PURE Way experience. All PURE operations team members are required to be familiar with the subject matter contained in the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual and abide by all outlined policies, processes, and procedures.

Please note that this manual is subject to periodic revision. All members of team PURE should remain aware of and review any changes to this manual as they occur. If discrepancies are discovered or if there are any questions, it is the responsibility of each team member to raise their concern to their direct supervisor for clarification.


Legal Disclaimer

The information contained within this document is proprietary, confidential, and for internal use only. No part of the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual may be printed, reproduced, or distributed without the express written consent of PURE Property Management, its representatives, or assignees.


PURE team members are not permitted to disclose the information contained within this document to Clients, Residents, Vendors, or the public, nor are they permitted to disclose any trade secrets of PURE Property Management including but not limited to management fees, commissions, referrals, and any other fees or associated programs; financial information; personnel compensation; personnel records; personnel conversations; Client records or conversations; management accounts; real estate sales or listings; marketing and/or strategic plans; or company projects, except as is required while performing the duties of their role within PURE Property Management.


Corporate Vision and Values

Led by a team of experienced property management industry professionals and seasoned technology innovators, PURE Property Management combines over 2,000 years of collective property management experience with the vision of leveraging world-class technology to deliver simple, satisfying experiences for all.

PURE values are what bands team PURE together in the mission of innovating property management.

Keep it SIMPLE

Complexity is the enemy. We strive for clean, simple, tech-driven solutions that deliver exceptional experiences.

Keep it REAL

We’re genuine, independent, yet united. We’re proud of who we are, know where we’re going and how to get there.

Keep it HONEST

Everyone trusts us to do the right, responsible thing with integrity and responsiveness. Never afraid to admit a mistake.

Keep it KIND

We’re kind, caring, and compassionate. We strive for work-life balance, with family always a priority.

BAND together (n+1)

Strength and success are found in greater numbers. We’re driven to grow our team of independent Rockstars.

BUILD together

By creating new technology and mashing up our collective hits, we build and deliver fresh, industry-leading experiences.

PLAY together

Collaboration is key to success. No solo artists on this label. We find the fun when we play well with each other.

WIN together

Our success is clearly defined, well-played, and thoughtfully measured. We strive to empower and hold ourselves accountable.

The policies, processes, and procedures outlined in the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual represent PURE’s best practices to standardize operations for all teams within the PURE family in alignment with PURE Corporate Values.


Regulatory Oversight

Residential property management activities are strictly regulated by several federal agencies, including the:

  • Internal Revenue Service (IRS)

  • US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

  • Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

  • Federal Trade Commission (FTC)

  • US Department of Justice (DOJ)


The policies, processes, and procedures within the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual are designed to ensure compliance with all federal regulations. Each member of Team PURE is personally responsible for ensuring that these policies, processes, and procedures are followed.


Further information regarding applicable laws and regulations may be found in Section 3 of the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual.


Document Control Procedure

The PURE Way Playbook is the single source of PURE Way Policy and Procedure for the operations of PURE Property Management. This document is subject to revision, and revision to this document must be made under the following Standard Operating Procedure.


Change Requests
Change Requests are submitted via the Change Request Form.

Change Requests are reviewed by the PURE Way Team for disposition and prioritization.

Does the change require a version change?

Is this a system or software-driven change?

Does this change require additional or re-training?

Change Requests can be used to request the creation of a new document or to document a process that has not yet been documented. Changes related to typographical errors, grammatical errors, punctuation, or broken hyperlinks will not require a version change or Change Notification.


Revision Process

The Revision Process must include the PURE Way Technical Writer, Christina Heldwein; Subject Matter Expert(s), Key Stakeholder(s), the Approver(s), and at least one member of the PURE Way Team.

When a revision is necessary, the document(s) requiring changes will be isolated and revised with the Secondary Stakeholders and the Technical Writer. A Google Doc with limited access will be used for revision development.

New and Revised Documents submitted for the PURE Way Playbook must be processed for publishing.


Change Notification

The audience defined for each Policy, Process, or Procedure indicates the primary operators to notify of a document change.

Playbook Versioning Notification

Playbook Versioning requires a written notice to destroy all previous versions of any documents contained within the Playbook

SOP and P&P Change Notification

Regulation Changes, Operational/ Task-related changes, or System-driven changes must be communicated to the appropriate audiences at the time of publication. Change Notifications will be sent to the Key Stakeholders for distribution to the defined audience.


PURE Way Playbook Change Request Form

As you know, the PURE Way Playbook is a thoughtful culmination of the most successful property management operations and a major training focus for 2024.  Totaling over 300 pages, with policies and step-by-step guides, we feel it’s pretty comprehensive.  That said, maybe we missed something.  Is there a gap in a process, or something we didn’t think of?  Did you spot a typo?  As you interact with the playbook, let us know.  Use the form below to submit a request to correct or modify an existing section of the current Playbook as we continue to build the PURE Way.

Roles and Responsibilities of PURE Centralized Operations

Diversity and Inclusion

As stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, PURE is committed to providing a work environment for all members of Team PURE that is welcoming, respectful, and engaging, with opportunities for personal and professional development. Having diverse teams, business partners and community relationships is vital to the spirit of collaboration and innovation that drives organic growth and success.


Policy Against Harassment, Discrimination, and Retaliation

PURE is committed to providing all applicants and team members with a safe and respectful working environment that is free from sexual harassment, as well as harassment and discrimination on the basis of actual or perceived race (including but not limited to the wearing of natural hairstyles such as afros, braids, twists, and locks), color, national origin, ancestry, religion, creed (including religious dress and grooming), citizenship status, sex or gender (including pregnancy, childbirth, and related medical conditions), gender identity or gender expression (including transgender status), sexual orientation, age, marital status, military service or veteran status, legally protected medical condition, physical or mental disability, genetic information, or any other characteristics under federal, state or local laws and ordinances (referred to as “protected characteristics”).

PURE maintains a strict policy that forbids sexual harassment and other harassment and discrimination against applicants or employees by co-workers, supervisors, managers, and professionals; furthermore, PURE will not tolerate harassment by its employees or non-employees with whom PURE has a business, service, or professional relationship, nor harassment of employees by non-employees, such as Clients, Vendors, contingent workers, and guests.

This policy applies at all company locations, company-sponsored social or other events, and other activities at which team PURE is represented. It applies to all areas of employment, including recruiting, hiring, placement, training, promotion, compensation, benefits, transfer, disciplinary action, employee activities, access to facilities and programs, general treatment during employment, and social and recreational programs. It is the personal responsibility of each member of Team PURE to be familiar with and abide by this policy.

All members of Team PURE are encouraged to report any incidents of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation immediately so that complaints can be quickly and fairly resolved. For guidance on complaint reporting and investigation, please refer to the PURE Employee Handbook.


Equal Employment Opportunity

PURE is an Equal Opportunity Employer that does not discriminate on the basis of actual or perceived race (including but not limited to the wearing of natural hairstyles such as afros, braids, twists, and locks), color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, citizenship status, age, sex or gender (including pregnancy), gender identity or expression (including transgender status), sexual orientation, marital status, veteran status, physical or mental disability, genetic information, or any other characteristic protected by applicable federal, state, or local laws.

It is PURE company policy to recruit, employ, retain, promote, terminate, and otherwise treat all team members and job applicants based on merit, qualifications, and competence. It is a violation of PURE policy to discriminate in the provision of employment opportunities, benefits, or privileges; to create discriminatory work conditions; or to use discriminatory evaluative standards in employment, if that discriminatory treatment is, in whole or in part, based on actual or perceived protected characteristics.

All members of Team PURE are encouraged to report any incidents of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation immediately so that complaints can be quickly and fairly resolved. For guidance on complaint reporting and investigation, please refer to the PURE Employee Handbook.


Code of Ethics

PURE conducts its affairs in strict compliance with the letter and spirit of the law and adherence to the highest principles of business ethics. Accordingly, all members of Team PURE must avoid activities that are in conflict, or give the appearance of being in conflict, with these principles and with the interests of the PURE. A conflict of interest exists when the team member’s loyalties or actions are divided between PURE interests and those of another, such as a competitor, supplier, or customer. Both the fact and the appearance of a conflict of interest should be avoided. Members of team PURE unsure as to whether a certain transaction, activity, or relationship constitutes a conflict of interest should discuss it with their immediate supervisor or the Managing Partners for clarification.


Standards of Conduct

The list outlined below is derived directly from the PURE Employee Handbook and provides examples of types of conduct that are not allowed at PURE. Engaging in misconduct of a type specifically designated here, or as otherwise described in the PURE Employee Handbook, may subject the engaging team member to disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. These examples do not identify every type of unacceptable conduct, and team members should be aware that any conduct detrimental to the interests of PURE, other team members, Residents, or Clients may result in disciplinary action up to and including immediate discharge.

  • Falsifying forms, records, reports, or other acts of dishonesty - PURE will not tolerate any falsified or misleading disclosures in company records, or the destruction, manipulation, or intentional misplacement of such records.

  • Excessive unexcused absenteeism or tardiness not otherwise protected by applicable law.

  • Poor performance, including refusal to perform lawful assigned tasks.

  • Engaging in altercations or harassment and interfering with the work performance of others.

  • Engaging in violent behavior, threats of violence, or any persistent malicious behavior that is known to have a high correlation to violent behavior, such as abusive conduct, intimidation, or conduct that demeans, degrades, or humiliates other employees.

  • Misusing or destroying PURE property or the property of another on PURE premises.

  • Failing to protect and respect all intellectual property belonging to the company or its Vendors, customers, partners, or business associates; i.e. the unauthorized use, copying, distribution, or alteration of company software or other intellectual property, or the intellectual property or third-party property of others entrusted to the company.

  • Violating duties of confidentiality.

  • Conducting non-business activities during the time paid by PURE and/or with PURE materials.

  • Possessing or bringing firearms or other dangerous weapons onto PURE premises.

  • Violating safety or health regulations, or otherwise engaging in conduct that creates a hazard.

  • Violating conflict of interest rules.

  • Being convicted of a crime that indicates unfitness for the job or raises a threat to the safety or well-being of PURE, its employees, customers, or property, to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law.

  • Non-compliance with company policies, including but not limited to policies contained in this manual, such as the Conflict of Interest Policy and Policy Against Harassment.

  • Non-compliance with all laws, rules, and regulations wherever the company does business.


PURE expects team members to be ethical, responsible, and in compliance with all applicable laws when conducting business or otherwise acting as a representative of the company.


Safety

As stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, it is of the utmost importance to PURE that safe working conditions are maintained for all team members, and that all team members remain safety conscious.

Any potential safety hazards at any site where PURE may conduct business should be reported immediately to management. Any injury, no matter how minor, during the course of employment must be reported promptly to the team member’s direct supervisor. Any member of team PURE who is injured on the job should seek medical treatment immediately.

In compliance with applicable law and to promote the concept of a safe workplace PURE maintains an Injury and Illness Prevention Program.


Emergencies

To protect the life and safety of PURE team members in the event of an emergency, PURE has developed an Emergency Action Plan applicable to all PURE locations, available for review at the PURE Way Resource Center. All members of team PURE should review this Emergency Action Plan carefully.


Security and Confidentiality

The security of PURE property and team members is critical and can be maintained only with the cooperation of all employees. Any breach of security should be immediately reported to management.


PURE property includes not only items such as computers and desks but also its proprietary and confidential information. Confidential information is of great importance to the future of PURE’s business, and it is the duty of each member of team PURE to maintain confidentiality even if the employment relationship with PURE ends. Prospective, current, and former members of team PURE are not to disclose any PURE confidential information to any person unless specifically authorized by PURE. Confidential information includes but is not limited to customer lists, computer records, financial data, details of engagement, process descriptions, technical and business information, research and development, production, manufacturing and engineering processes, finances, customers, and marketing and production and future business plans of PURE.

Team members are expected, as a condition of employment, to sign PURE’s At-Will Employment Confidential Information, Invention, and Assignment Agreement setting forth these duties in detail. Nothing in this section is intended to prohibit team members from discussing their own terms and conditions of employment.


Document Use, Storage, and Disposition

Policies outlined in this section of the PURE Way Operations and Policy Manual apply to all PURE Property Management documents without exception. Each department follows specific processes designed to best suit the regulatory requirements of its operations and location.

For all documents not stored within a PMS:

  • When a document has reached its respective maturity date, discard the document electronically or physically.


Property Management and Leasing Documents

  • Documents that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by system definitions approved by the PURE Way Team.


Documents that are not utilized or processed through a PMS are retained on their office-specific Google Drive for a minimum of 3 years, or in accordance with state/local law.


Accounting Documents 

Documents that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by system definitions approved by the PURE Way Team.

Documents that are not utilized or processed through a PMS are retained on a designated Google Drive for a minimum of 6 months, or in accordance with state/local law.


Human Resources

PURE Human Resources follows state and federal record retention guidelines.

  • Personnel files are maintained for a minimum of 4 years after the end of employment.

  • Employment applications are kept on file for a minimum of 1 year after disposition.

  • OSHA logs and Injury Reports are maintained for a minimum of 5 years after the reporting period.

California record retention practices currently cover all states in which PURE operates. In the event that guidelines exceeding the stringency of California are identified, PURE Human Resources will act to remain in compliance.


The information recorded in each member of team PURE’s personnel file is extremely important both to the team members and to management. It is each team member’s responsibility to make sure that the personal data in the file is accurate and up to date.

PURE does not disclose any nonpublic personal information about our team members or former team members to anyone, except as authorized by the team member or as required or permitted by law. PURE maintains physical, electronic, and procedural safeguards that comply with federal standards to safeguard nonpublic personal information.


Maintenance

Documents that are utilized within a PMS are retained and dispositioned by definitions approved by PURE Property Management.

OSHA logs and Injury Reports are maintained for a minimum of 5 years after the reporting period.


Media Inquiry Policy

All public relations activities and media requests regarding PURE will be coordinated and managed to ensure the dissemination of only accurate and appropriate information to the public and to provide a positive, professional appearance of PURE and PURE products. Therefore, all media inquiries regarding the position of PURE as to any issues must be referred to a PURE-authorized spokesperson. Only the approved spokespersons are authorized to make or approve public statements on behalf of PURE. No member of team PURE, unless specifically designated, is authorized to make statements on behalf of the company. Any member of team PURE wishing to write and/or publish an article, paper, blog, or other publication on behalf of PURE must first obtain approval from PURE.

Nothing in this policy is meant to, nor should it be interpreted to, in any way limit the rights of any member of Team PURE under any applicable federal, state, or local laws, including rights under the National Labor Relations Act to engage in protected concerted activities with other team members to improve terms and conditions of employment, such as wages and benefits.


Use of Company Owned Vehicles and Equipment

As stated in the PURE Employee Handbook, PURE may provide vehicles for business use to allow employees to drive on company-designated business. The company may also reimburse employees for business use of personal vehicles according to the guidelines below. The company retains the right to amend or terminate this policy at any time. The term “vehicle” as used in this policy includes but is not limited to cars, trucks, SUVs, and other types of vehicles considered to be “street legal” according to traffic laws in the United States.

Team members may not drive any company vehicles without the prior approval of their direct supervisor. Members of team PURE approved to drive on company business are required to inform their supervisor of any changes that may affect either their legal or physical ability to drive or their continued insurability. Team members holding jobs requiring regular driving for business as an essential job function must, as a condition of employment, be able to meet the driver approval standards of this policy at all times.

Members of team PURE who drive a vehicle on company business must, in addition to meeting the approval requirements above, exercise due diligence to drive safely and to maintain the security of the vehicle and its contents. This includes not using the vehicle in a manner prohibited by the vehicle manufacturer. The use of handheld cell phones while behind the wheel of a moving vehicle being used on company business is strictly prohibited. Team members are solely responsible for any driving infractions or fines as a result of their driving.

Non-employees and non-business passengers are prohibited from riding in company vehicles. Team members must report any accident, theft, or malicious damage involving a company vehicle to their supervisor and Human Resources, regardless of the extent of damage or lack of injuries.

Company vehicles must be inspected quarterly; such inspection shall utilize a Vehicle Inspection Form available from Human Resources for the team member and that team member’s direct supervisor to fill out for submission to the company. The installation or addition of performance enhancements, alterations, or other after-market accessories to company vehicles are strictly prohibited.


Company Logo and Marketing Materials

All marketing materials must be approved by a PURE Marketing team member. Reach out to the #ask-marketing channel on Slack for assistance, to obtain proofs. or for approval if you're creating marketing or operational collateral involving brand identity.

Roles and Responsibilities of PURE Centralized Operations


Regional Director

The Regional Director is responsible for leading and managing the Operators and/or Operations Managers of multiple offices, in many cases across large regions or states, to achieve business goals and maximize profitability. The purpose of the Regional Director of Operations is to effectively guide leaders in the assigned geographic area, set performance objectives, evaluate and optimize operational performance, ensure company standards are upheld, and prepare operations and financial reports.


Operations Manager

The Operations Manager is accountable for all office operations. The Operations Manager effectively manages and coordinates persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish property objectives as set forth by PURE. The Operations Manager will participate in the creation and implementation of strategies, operational procedures, and policy development.


Senior Property Manager

The Senior Property Manager is accountable for all property operations. The purpose of the Senior Property Manager is to effectively manage and coordinate persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish company objectives in concert with objectives set forth by the Client. These objectives include maximizing occupancy levels and property values. The Senior Property Manager is the direct point of contact for PURE Clients.


Property Manager

The Property Manager works as a key player on the property management team to deliver exceptional service to Residents in their assigned portfolio. The purpose of the Property Manager is to effectively manage and coordinate persons, activities, and available resources to accomplish company objectives while creating a superb Resident experience. The Property Manager is the direct point of contact for PURE Residents.


Assistant Property Manager

The Assistant Property Manager assists the Property Manager with Client satisfaction and retention by promoting Resident relations through ongoing follow-through and communication in all aspects of the property management cycle. The Assistant Property Manager maintains excellent Resident relations while assisting the Property Manager in communicating with Residents, both verbally and in writing.

Business Development Representative

The Business Development Representative is accountable for all organic Client growth and new property onboarding. The Business Development Representative must effectively market PURE Property Management services, generate leads on prospective Clients, contact prospective Clients, present company services, and secure new management contracts. The Business Development Representative must be able to relate to all people, have a Client-first attitude, possess a high degree of professional and ethical standards, and carry out duties with prompt execution and exceptional follow-through.


Leasing Specialist

The Leasing Specialist is accountable for promoting properties, responding to inquiries, qualifying prospective tenants, processing applications according to company-established policies in a timely manner, and maximizing occupancy levels. The Leasing Specialist must display tech-savviness, great communication, organizational, and sales skills. As the face of PURE Property Management, a friendly and helpful demeanor is essential to being successful in this position.


Maintenance Coordinator

The Maintenance Coordinator assists the property management team with client satisfaction and retention by promoting resident relations through ongoing follow-through and communication in all aspects of the property management cycle. The Maintenance Coordinator maintains excellent resident relations when communicating with residents and owners, answering inquiries about maintenance request status, approval of estimates, and general recommendations.


After Hours Maintenance Services Representative

The After Hours Maintenance Services Representative assists the property management team with client satisfaction and retention by communicating with residents and owners, answering  inquiries about maintenance request status, and dispatching emergency maintenance services after normal business hours.


Field Technician

The Maintenance Field Technician responds to PURE Property Management resident service requests with a professional demeanor, in a timely fashion and is a driving force behind exceptional customer service. A general knowledge of maintenance functions such as basic plumbing, electric, and carpentry skills are required. A keen eye for detail, effective communication with residents both written and verbal, organization, and physical stamina are important qualities for this position.

Operations Staff Accountant

The Staff Accountant provides accounting support for one or more PURE Property Management locations to accomplish company goals and objectives and conducts all PURE accounting transactions as defined by the policies and procedures established by the PURE Finance/Accounting Department and Trust Accounting and Compliance Department. Policies may vary by state as established by licensing authorities and trust account compliance requirements or by HOA as established by Board requests, association needs, and/or governing documents.

The PURE Resident Benefits Package

A Resident Benefits Package (RBP) is a collection of services and amenities that a renter can only get from a professional management company. Whatever the package includes, it makes the things that Residents and property management professionals have to do easier! The PURE RBP currently includes:

$1M Identity Protection

All adult leaseholders get $1M coverage backed by AIG, monitoring through IBM's Watson, and a dedicated US-Based Identity Restoration Specialist.

Filter Delivery Service

Changing filters is as easy as opening the front door! This service helps save up to $250/year and reduces the hassles of repairs.

24/7 Maintenance Coordination

24/7 Maintenance Coordination makes reporting maintenance issues easy and fast for Residents online or via phone.

Online Portal Access

Residents can access documents and pay rent through our easy-to-use online portal! 

Credit Building

Each on-time rent payment helps build credit with an average Resident credit score increase of 23 to 42 points.

Resident Rewards Program

Rent day is now rewarded for the Resident! Residents receive in-app cash, gift cards, and more for paying their rent on time. 

Late Fee Forgiveness

PURE offers one-time late fee forgiveness per calendar year.

Insurance Policy 

Residents can opt-in to Renter Content Coverage, Tenant Liability Insurance Coverage, and Renter's Bodily Injury Coverage via Plan A.

The PURE Animal Program

The Animal Program offered by PURE provides each property with the opportunity to have a standardized, succinct, and worry-free animal policy to which Residents can add or remove an animal at any time.


A PetScreening profile for each adult leaseholder, created at application or renewal, provides a record of all animals on the property, verifies the legitimacy of Assistance Animals, and creates a legally binding agreement between the Resident and PURE Property Management as Residents attest that they have read and agree to pet policies set forth by PURE.

For all pet-owning Residents, the minimum insurance liability coverage is $100,000. As a condition of allowing Residents to have pets at a property, where allowable by state or local law:

  • Residents with animals will be required to have any carpets professionally cleaned, deodorized, and treated for fleas and provide evidence of said cleaning/treatment upon Move-Out

  • An annual property evaluation will be performed at a cost to the Resident

In accordance with federal guidance, Residents with an Assistance Animal will never be asked to pay any fees applicable to pets under the Animal Program. 


Animal Program Fees

Up-Front Fees Due at Lease Signing

  • Pet Administration Fee: $400 for the first pet; $250 per additional pet thereafter

  • Tank/Cage Pet Administration Fee*: $250 per enclosure

*for animals like fish and birds, which would be kept in tanks/cages


Monthly Fees

  • FIDO Score™ of 3 or higher: $30/month, per pet

  • FIDO Score™ 2: $50/month, per pet

  • FIDO Score™of 1:  $80/month, per pet


Animals that cannot be assigned a FIDO Score™ through PetScreening (e.g., fish and birds) will be considered as having a FIDO Score™ of 3.

Annual Fees

  • Annual Property Evaluation: $75

  • PetScreening Profile Renewal*: $25 paid to PetScreening

*only pet owners will need to pay the profile renewal fee as Assistance Animal and no-pet profiles renew at no cost to the Resident


GL Codes

  • 4470 Monthly Pet Fee

  • 4475 Annual Pet Evaluation

  • 4480 Non-Refundable Pet Fee

Note: If your local or state law limits or dictates a maximum allowable upfront and/or recurring fee, please share this information with the PURE Way Team.


The Enhanced Damage Program

PURE Property Management offers the Enhanced Damage Program (EDP) to all Owners who agree to allow PURE to offer their property as “pets negotiable” or “pet friendly.'' As a part of this program, PURE agrees to repair any documented pet damage, up to $2,000 per lease, for pet damages exceeding the Resident's Security Deposit or SDRP coverage. Security Deposit and/or SDRP funds must be exhausted as a condition precedent to triggering the EDP.

The Enhanced Damage Program only applies to leases that have PURE-approved and registered pets. Undisclosed and unauthorized pets are not included in the EDP. Additionally, any damage caused by Assistance Animals is not covered under the EDP and is the sole responsibility of the Resident.

The EDP is terminated immediately upon termination of the management agreement between the property Owner and PURE PM.


Unauthorized Animals

Unauthorized animals discovered on a property are considered a lease violation, and where permitted by law, can be grounds to begin the eviction process.

If a Resident fails to disclose an animal at any point during the term of the Residential Rental Agreement, at the office’s discretion the Resident may be allowed to complete the animal screening process to certify any unauthorized animal. The Resident will be obligated to pay a $100 processing fee, plus the lesser of all applicable pet fees associated with the screening of the animal and all monthly pet fees back to the Residential Rental Agreement inception date or a $500 fee.


The PURE Security Deposit Replacement Program

The Security Deposit Replacement Program (SDRP) offers Residents a choice between paying thetraditional security deposit or paying a non-refundable monthly fee for the duration of their occupancy instead. The monthly fee is not held by PURE, but paid to YRIG for Security Deposit Insurance on which PURE is the insured party.

To qualify for enrollment in the SDRP, new applicants must have a fully-approved rental application. Applicants who are approved with conditions are not eligible for the SDRP during their first year of Residency, but may become eligible at renewal based upon their performance as a Resident.

Residents remain legally responsible for damages, repairs, and fees and PURE is protected from losses in the event that the Resident refuses to pay. The SDRP coverage amount - the “Band level” - is calculated at 1x the monthly rent, rounded up to the next $500 increment. The monthly fee is determined using the SDRP Rate Sheet.

Self-Access Property Showings

In order to secure a Resident for a property, it is required to grant access to a potential applicant using the PURE-approved platform for self-showings. For properties that are not accessible for self-showings, e.g., a home in a gated community, showings will be conducted by appointment only.

Barring extenuating circumstances, the applicant or a representative of the applicant is required to view the property in person prior to submitting an application.


Vendor Management

Vendors used for repairs, maintenance, and property management are all screened and approved as PURE Vendors. In order to become a PURE Vendor, the Vendor must provide:

  • A completed PURE Vendor Onboarding Worksheet

  • Current business license(s), in accordance with federal and state requirements

  • Proof of Liability Insurance, COI at $1,000,000

  • A certificate holder for the office location

  • A completed W9

  • A completed ACH Form for direct deposit

  • Where applicable, proof of Worker’s Compensation Insurance at $1,000,000


It is the Vendor’s responsibility to provide PURE with renewed licenses, insurance policies, and updated tax or banking information. The Maintenance Coordinator is responsible for verifying and entering the updated information in PURE’s Vendor database(s).

PURE requires a standard of service and Client/Resident experience from all PURE Vendors, measured upon the following principles:

Workmanship Quality

In the event that a Vendor shows a pattern of recurring negligence, poor workmanship, code/ regulation non-compliance, or otherwise insufficient service, PURE reserves the right to remove that Vendor from the PURE platform.

Market Value Alignment

PURE selects Vendors with consideration to their alignment with the current local market for the costs of materials and labor.

Timely and Accurate Billing

Vendors are required to comply with the PURE Vendor Invoicing Policy, and a pattern of inaccurate or untimely billing may result in removal from the PURE platform.

Availability

A Vendor with limited availability, or who shows a pattern of frequent cancellations may be removed from the PURE platform.

The Maintenance Coordinator is responsible for tracking Vendor pricing and patterns of negative Resident feedback, poor workmanship, and lapses of required documentation. In the event of aberration from PURE’s standard of service, the Maintenance Coordinator is authorized to recommend corrective action to the Vendor or to recommend the Vendor's removal from the PURE platform to their direct supervisor.

Vendor Invoicing Policy

All invoices must be submitted to PURE through PropertyMeld. Vendors are requested to issue one invoice per work order. Invoices should be charged for the full amount of the work order, except where there is a written agreement by both parties confirming a specific arrangement of invoicing.

Invoice Content

In accordance with IRS requirements, all invoices must include the following:

  • The title “Invoice” clearly displayed

  • PURE office name (e.g., PURE Property Management - North Bay Office)

  • Invoice date

  • Payment terms

  • A unique invoice number

  • A description of the products or services sold

  • The quantity and price of each product/service

  • The date that products/services were delivered

  • The total amount due

  • Sales tax, where applicable

PURE Property Management will return any invoices that do not contain these items, as they are not in compliance with IRS guidelines.

Invoice Payment

Unless otherwise agreed upon and specified on the invoice, PURE Property Management will render payment within 30 days of receiving the invoice. PURE Property Management does not approve rolling unpaid charges to another invoice number.


Managing Negative Feedback and Complaints

As soon as negative feedback or a complaint is received, it must be escalated to the office Operations Manager for attention. The Operations Manager will proceed with managing the matter based on the nature of the feedback or the complaint.

The PURE Way Corporate Brand Messaging and Communications Guidebook is available through the PURE Way Resource Center and offers guidance on managing negative feedback.

For HUD, EPA, DRE, and other legal complaints, the Operations Manager will consult the PURE Legal Team for guidance or a local reference. Additional guidance can be found within the PURE Way Resource Center. 


Acceptable Forms of Payment

Application Fees

Fees associated with submitting an application for a rental property must be paid online via the PMS via credit/debit card at the time of application.


Move-In Fees

Move-In fees may be paid via credit/debit card 5 business days prior to taking possession of the property. Additionally, move-in fees may be paid via certified check, cashier’s check, or money order. Please note that the Security Deposit, if applicable, must be paid separately from all other move-in fees.


Annual Fees

Any annual fees must be paid online via the PMS.


Monthly Fees

Any monthly fees must be paid online via the PMS.

Other Fees

Any other fees not defined above must be paid online via the PMS.


Mold, Mildew, and Lead-Based Paint

It is PURE policy to furnish all appropriate disclosures and addendums related to Mold, Mildew, and Lead-Based Paint to the Resident based on the age and location of the property.

The Resident has a responsibility to maintain the property to inhibit mold growth, and the Resident's agreement to do so is part of the Resident's material consideration in the Residential Rental Agreement. By signing the Residential Rental Agreement, Residents agree to:

  • Maintain the premises free of dirt, debris, and moisture that can harbor mold

  • Clean any found mildew and/or mold with an appropriate cleaner designed to kill mold

  • Clean and dry any visible moisture on windows, walls, and other surfaces, including personal property, as quickly as possible

  • Use reasonable care to close all windows and other openings on the property to prevent water from entering the property

  • Use exhaust fans, if any, in the bathroom(s) and kitchen while using those facilities and notify PURE PM of any inoperative exhaust fans promptly

  • Immediately notify PURE of any water intrusion

  • Immediately notify PURE of overflows from bathroom, kitchen or laundry facilities

  • Immediately notify PURE of any significant mold growth found on any surfaces on the property

  • Allow PURE, with appropriate notice, to enter the property and make inspections regarding mold and ventilation

  • Release, indemnify, hold harmless, and forever discharge PURE PM and PURE PM's employees, agents, successors, and assigns from any and all claims, liabilities, or causes of action of any kind that the Resident, members of the Resident's household or the Resident's guests or invitees may have at any time against PURE or PURE agents resulting from the presence of mold due to the Resident's failure to comply 


For all properties built before 1978, it is a requirement for all PURE offices to have disclosures on file identifying the possible existence of lead in that property. The Federal LBP Brochure should be uploaded in the PMS as a global shared document, accessible to Residents and Clients.

The BDR will get the Federal lead-based paint disclosure document signed by the owner of all new doors if the property or properties occurred prior to 1978; each office will retain a copy of this form to be used with all new leases moving forward.

If the new door has a Resident already in place, the PM will need to ensure a copy signed by both the owner and resident is in the PMS as part of the lease packet.

When a Resident’s lease is up for renewal the PM must ensure that:

  • The Federal lead-based document signed by the owner and Resident is present in the PMS

  • The Resident has been provided with the EPA-published brochure “Protecting Your Family from Lead in Your Home”


When a new prospective Resident is signing a lease the PM must:

  • Make a PDF copy of the original Federal form signed by the Owner to be part of the lease packet

  • Provide the new Resident with the EPA-published brochure “Protect Your Family from Lead in Your Home”


Additional guidance is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.


Resident Illness, Hospitalization, or Death

In the event a PURE Resident experiences serious illness, hospitalization or death, the priority of all team members is to exercise professionalism and empathy in all interactions at all times.

PURE does not offer an abatement of monthly fees in the event that a Resident falls ill and or is hospitalized. It is the responsibility of the Resident to provide any gap insurance that may cover accruing rent.

In the event of Resident death, applicable PURE team members should activate the appropriate PURE Workflow to either modify the Residential Rental Agreement or begin the Move-Out Process.


Smoke Alarms, and Carbon Monoxide Detectors

The presence of installed smoke alarms in every home is a federal legal requirement and PURE company policy. Each office, however, is to defer to more stringent state and local requirements should they arise. At a minimum, PURE properties are required to have smoke alarms in all bedrooms and hallways on each level of the home. Smoke detectors may be installed only by members of team PURE, or by a PURE-approved Vendor.

Most states, although not all, require that carbon monoxide detectors also be installed in the home. It is the responsibility of each member of team PURE to be familiar with state and local legislation impacting PURE operations.

At the discretion of each office, combination smoke and carbon monoxide detectors may be purchased and installed by PURE-approved Vendors.
