Team PURE Expectation

As mentioned in Section 2, residential property management is highly regulated by a number of federal agencies, and the policies, processes, and procedures contained within the PURE Way Playbook Operations and Policy Manual are designed to ensure compliance with all federal regulations.

Each member of Team PURE is personally responsible for ensuring that these policies, processes, and procedures are followed. The PURE Legal team is available to assist in ensuring compliance with all regulations. Information on how to contact PURE Legal and respond to any complaints received from HUD, the EPA, the Department of Real Estate, or any other agency can be located within the PURE Way Resource Center.

State and Local Level Variability

Each state has an organization responsible for regulating and auditing the real estate activities within its jurisdiction. As such, it is acknowledged that there may be significant state and local level variability regarding residential property management rules and regulations in addition to federal regulations. Specific state and local regulations of residential property management are not described within this document. It is the responsibility of PURE team members to understand and be familiar with the state and local rules that govern property management activity within their geographic area. PURE Legal may be contacted for assistance if needed.


The Fair Housing Act

It is PURE company policy that people of similar income and qualification benchmarks shouldhave the same housing opportunities available to them, regardless of personal characteristics such as race, color, religion, national origin, sex, familial status, or disability.

PURE Property Management actively seeks to comply with all aspects of the Fair Housing Act by:

  • Expecting all members of team PURE to adhere to Fair Housing Guidelines set forth by HUD

  • Providing rigorous training on Fair Housing Guidelines on an annual basis and to all new hires

Additional information on the Fair Housing Act, including federal and state resources, is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.


The Americans With Disabilities Act

PURE Property Management, as required by law, facilitates Reasonable Accommodations within the recommendations of the Americans with Disabilities Act for all persons with disabilities.

Additional information on Reasonable Accommodations, including federal and state resources, is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.


The Servicemembers’ Civil Relief Act of 2003, SCRA

PURE Property Management acknowledges and abides by the SCRA, the federal law designed to protect service members by providing unique rights to lease termination in addition to other protective provisions.

Additional information on the SCRA is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.


The Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair, and Painting (RRP) Rule

In accordance with the EPA’s Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair and Painting (RRP) Rule, it is PURE company policy that a disclosure identifying the possible existence of lead-based paint be on file within the PMS for all homes constructed prior to 1978. Residents moving into a home constructed prior to 1978 must be provided with the EPA-published brochure, “Protect Your Family From Lead in Your Home.”

Additional information on the Lead-Based Paint Renovation, Repair, and Painting (RRP) Rule is available within the PURE Way Resource Center.


The Uniform Regulations of Landlord-Tenant Act, URLTA

In accordance with guidelines set forth by the URLTA, in applicable states, PURE is committed to:

  • Compliance with applicable building and housing codes affecting health and safety

  • Making all necessary repairs to put and keep premises in a fit and habitable condition

  • Keeping all common Residential areas in a clean and safe condition

  • Maintaining electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning, and other facilities and appliances in “good and safe working order and condition”

  • Providing and maintaining appropriate receptacles for the removal of garbage and other waste, and arranging for their removal

  • Supplying running water and reasonable amounts of hot water at all times and reasonable heat (between October 1 and May 1), except where the law does not require the building to be so equipped, or heat or hot water is generated by an installation controlled by the tenant

As defined in the Tenant Obligations section of URLTA, the Resident is responsible for notifying PURE of all maintenance issues as promptly as possible. Residents are expected to submit maintenance requests through PropertyMeld. The costs of repairs are charged against the Client's reserve funds unless repairs are deemed a result of negligence or non-compliance with the Lease Agreement. States that have adopted and enforced URLTA guidelines include Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Washington.


The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA)

PURE Property Management is an Equal Opportunity Organization, and, as such, strives to remain in compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act for all applications or onboarding processes that utilize consumer reports. Like the Fair Housing Act, the ECOA prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, source of income, and a history of rights exercised under the Consumer Credit Protection Act.


The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)

During the course of normal business operations background checks, which are consumer reports, are used to make decisions regarding applicant eligibility. A consumer report may contain information such as a person’s credit characteristics, rental history, or criminal history and is protected by the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, PURE requests consumer reports only when permitted for normal business operations. Additionally, PURE provides a notice of adverse action following the rejection of an application or the issuance of a conditional acceptance.


The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA)

The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act amends the FCRA with provisions allowing consumers the right to one free credit report per year from credit reporting agencies. Consumers may also purchase, for a reasonable fee, a credit score along with information about how the credit score is calculated.

The Act also adds provisions designed to prevent and mitigate identity theft, including a section that enables consumers to place fraud alerts in their credit files, as well as other enhancements to the Fair Credit Reporting Act.


The CAN-SPAM Act

PURE company policy dictates adherence to a high standard of professionalism, accuracy, and confidentiality in communications with Residents, Clients, and Vendors. In accordance with the CAN-SPAM Act, PURE strives to uphold a standard of truthful, fair, and appropriate communication in all areas of business.

New Client Acquisition

A “Client” is defined as a property investor or owner with one or more properties who wishes to hire PURE to manage their assets. When an inquiry or lead for property management services comes to any member of team PURE, that team member should collect the following:

  • Potential Client’s full name

  • Potential Client’s phone number

  • Potential Client’s email address

  • City, state, and zip code of prospective new doors


Questions from the potential Client should be recorded and directed to the PURE Business Development team along with the potential Client’s contact information and property details. The Business Development Representative (BDR) is responsible for Property Management Agreement negotiations, property benchmarking, and closing.

All information regarding the lead may be directed to the PURE Business Development team via Slack on the #ask-business-development channel. Information should be shared using the template below.

New BDR Opportunity
Potential Client’s full name
Potential Client’s phone number
Potential Client’s email address
City, state, and zip code of prospective new doors

Benchmarking a Property

The BDR will analyze the financial characteristics of, or “benchmark,” for all potential properties to see how they compare to similar properties in the same market. To be approved for inclusion on the PURE platform, potential properties must meet the following benchmarking criteria:

  • The property must rent for at least 85% of the average rent in the local market.

  • There may not be any trailers on the property, regardless of permanent foundation.

  • The property may not be furnished - PURE does not take the inventory.

  • There may not be any personal inventory left behind from the Client.

  • There may not be a Client and/or one of their family members living on the property.

  • The property must be located within 50 miles of the management office.

  • The property may not have any shared living spaces.

  • The property may not have any HUD/Section 8/State Voucher Residents unless required by state law.

  • The property may not have a Client who interferes with the management of their asset.

  • The property may not have any Client controlled cameras.

  • The property may only use PURE documents and PURE-approved Vendors for the duration of the property management agreement.

  • The property cannot have a trampoline. If it does, it must be removed prior to rental.

  • If the property has a swimming pool, the Client is responsible for all costs associated with maintenance and repair.

  • If the property is Resident Occupied, proof of good standing/Rent Payment History is required 

  • Review Residential Rental Agreements of all resident-occupied properties being considered.

If the result of the benchmarking exercise determines that the property is not eligible for inclusion on the PURE platform, then the BDR will connect with the potential Client to recommend corrective action and halt the acquisition process until the time that corrective action is taken.

If the result of the benchmarking exercise determines the property is eligible for inclusion on the PURE platform, then the BDR will contact the Client to facilitate an on-site evaluation of the potential property or properties.

Negotiating the Property Management Agreement

The Property Management Agreement (PMA) is the legal contract that governs the terms of the relationship between PURE and the Client.

The standard 12-month PURE PMA is used as a baseline contract for all potential Clients and contains specific language that outlines how changes in terms are managed. Some clauses may be negotiated by the BDR within allowable parameters; for example, the BDR has the discretion outlined below to negotiate the terms of all fees and offer discounts depending on specific circumstances of the potential Client’s portfolio:

  • On an individual single-family home, PURE’s standard management fee is 10% of the monthly rent; however, when a Client brings 3 or more doors to the PURE platform, it is permissible for the BDR to negotiate the management fee to no less than 8%.

  • The management fee is earned in full at the beginning of the agreement; however, provisions exist that allow it to be billed and paid monthly.

○ If/when the Client chooses to terminate the PMA the management fee due accelerates. The PURE PMA contains language outlining management fee acceleration upon Client termination.


Additional fees apply as defined in the PURE PMA. These include:

  • Client start-up fees, intended to cover the cost of welcoming a new Client

  • Leasing fees, enacted when PURE negotiates a new Residential Rental Agreement

  • Additional fees as defined and enacted by PURE

Before the execution of the PMA, all fees billable to the Client must be disclosed and acknowledged.


Documentation and Forms

The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to complete the Client Onboarding Package (COP) once the PMA has been signed and executed. The Client Onboarding Package (COP) encompasses the following:

  • Client Intake Form, completed by a new Client to provide full and complete information as a part of the PURE Client Onboarding process

  • PURE Client Direct Deposit Form, giving PURE permission to electronically debit or credit money from a Client’s bank, credit union, or prepaid card account when payment is due

  • Insurance Authorization, a copy of the Client’s Insurance policy authorizing PURE Property Management as an added insured party where permitted by state or local law

  • HOA/COA documents, if applicable

  • Utility Authorization Form, authorizing team PURE to manage utility transfers on behalf of the Client

  • Client Self-Access Authorization Form, permitting PURE to expand visibility and accessibility of the vacant rental property by allowing for self-showings


All documents must be signed and dated in the correct locations, and loaded with the Client and property into the PMS. Responsiveness to the Client is critical during Client Onboarding and is the responsibility of all PURE team members associated with the process.

Client Insurance

Coverage thresholds are defined within the PMA, and PURE Clients are required to carry insurance appropriate to the size and value of their portfolio. Clients must provide a copy of their insurance policy. Where applicable by law, PURE should be listed by the Client on their policy as an additional insured party.

Client Reserve Accounts

PURE Clients are required to establish and fund a “reserve” account to fund property emergencies, minor maintenance requests, and on-site repairs. This reserve may also be used in cases where the Client is non-responsive to PURE communications. 


The reserve account must be established before the completion of onboarding, and funded with a minimum amount of $500 per door. If necessary, the account may be partially or fully funded with the proceeds of a Resident’s first-month rent.


Storing and Reviewing Client Documentation

The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to create a new folder in the office’s dedicated Google Drive titled with the Client’s name. All documentation will be added to this Google Drive, and the Client’s tax ID will be verified using IRS Taxpayer Identification Matching (TIN) Tools. Once the Client’s tax ID has been verified, the Senior Property Manager will collaborate with their Pod members to create a new Client Profile and portal within the PMS. All forms in the COP must be loaded into the PMS.

End Management Flow

The Senior Property Manager is the main point of contact for any day-to-day operations that require the approval or notification of the Client. The Senior Property Manager handles all Client correspondence, including PMA Renewals, Client Contributions, and any other matters that pertain to the Client’s portfolio. If the Senior Property Manager is unavailable and there is an immediate need, then the Operations Manager is the next point of contact. 


The Senior Property Manager begins their relationship with the Client following the execution of the initial PMA. The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the BDR to onboard the Client and will collaborate with their Pod to enter the portfolio into the PURE platform and begin management operations for the property or properties. Completion of the PURE Vendor Onboarding Process is required for any Client-preferred Vendors. The Senior Property Manager will collaborate with the Maintenance team to onboard new Vendors. During the relationship between PURE Property Management and the Client, the Residents should have no direct contact with the Client.

Property Needs Assessment

Following Client and Property Onboarding within the Property Management System, the Senior Property Manager will collaborate with their Pod members and Centralized Maintenance to assess the new Client’s property holdings and needs.

If

|

Then

The new property is currently Resident-occupied,

|

Contact the Resident to schedule a Property Evaluation.

The new property is currently Resident-occupied,
AND
The Resident is planning to move out,

|

Contact the Resident to schedule an initial Property Evaluation.

Follow procedures for Resident Move-Out, Vacancy Management, and Marketing a Property for Rent.

The new property is not currently Resident-occupied,

|

Contact the Client to schedule a Rent Ready Evaluation of the Property.

Circumstances may arise under which the Client still lives in the home at the time of joining the PURE platform; in this circumstance, there must be a clear timeline for the Client to vacate the property and allow for any updates required to make the property rent-ready for a new Resident.

In addition to the above circumstances, the Client may be uncertain about whether they want to rent or sell their property. In such a scenario, it is permissible to simultaneously list a property for both sale and rent under the following conditions:

  • PURE is the listing agent for the sale

  • PURE is the property management company of record for the property

If both of these conditions are not met, a simultaneous listing is not acceptable. If the property is already occupied the Resident is not required to complete a new Residential Rental Agreement on the PURE platform until their lease renewal date, unless there is a violation or non-compliance with state or local law. PURE does not currently charge an additional fee to manage existing non-conforming leases.

If the occupying Resident has an existing month-to-month Residential Rental Agreement, the occupying Resident must complete the application process via the PURE platform to convert to a 12-month lease immediately, barring extenuating circumstances.

Client approval must be obtained if there is an extenuating circumstance necessitating the creation of a lease term outside of the standard 12-month PURE lease.

If the new property is currently Resident occupied, the Property Manager will review new Resident information and enter all applicable data into the PMS, including:

  • lease documents

  • application documents

  • evaluation reports

  • photos/videos

  • security deposit

  • pet/animal information, if applicable

Client Connection

The Property Management team is responsible for maintaining the relationship with the Investor Client. Use Client Connection Calls for guidance to manage your PURE-Client relationship. 


Client Termination Flow

If, during the term of the lease, a Client chooses to sell or move into a property or terminate the Residential Rental Agreement for any other reason within legal limits, PURE will follow the Residential Rental Agreement and Property Management Agreement until the property is either closed out or onboarded with a new Client.


Collect Management Fees

Before the termination date, collect all management fee balances due under the terms of the Property Management Agreement. As a best practice, they should be collected from either the Resident’s rent received or the Client’s reserve account.


Transfer the Security Deposit

While the property is still Resident-occupied, the PM Pod will transfer the security deposit back to the Client by creating a check that is made out to the Client.

The PM Pod will notify the Resident(s) that the security deposit for that property has been transferred to the Client.

If the Resident is enrolled in the Security Deposit Replacement Program (SDRP) there is no security deposit to return. Instead, provide the Client with the appropriate termination form to re-disclose what is ending.

Terminate Maintenance Services

The Client must be informed that, after the termination date, PURE can no longer coordinate maintenance for their property; any maintenance in progress at the time of termination must be handed off to the Client.

Documents Client Termination Reasons

For internal tracking purposes, the Senior PM will capture the Client’s reason(s) for terminating the PMA. Generally, the reasons should be grouped into one of three categories:

  • Good Churn

  • Neutral Churn

  • Bad Churn

The reason for churn will be tracked by PURE to obtain key management insights that can be used to provide feedback to teams or update processes and procedures.

“Good churn” offers additional benefits from the transaction, for example:

  • A Client terminates the PMA because they have sold the property and PURE has brokered the sale

  • A Client terminates the PMA because they have sold the property and the new Client of that property signs a new PMA with PURE

“Neutral churn” occurs when:

  • The Client chooses to move back into their property

  • The Client sells the home, but PURE does not broker the sale

  • The Client sells the home, but PURE does not retain the new Client

There are several “bad” churn scenarios that could potentially be captured:

  • The Client is not satisfied with PURE’s service

  • The Client has decided to self-manage the property

  • The Client has hired a new Property Manager that offers some level of differentiation from PURE

  • PURE initiates the termination of the relationship due to non-performance by the Client

Regardless of their rationale for leaving the PURE platform, the Operations Manager will reach out to the terminating Client to facilitate the exit survey, obtain feedback, and express PURE’s gratitude for the business relationship.

The Senior Property Manager will ensure a smooth transition during Client Termination.

Centralized Leasing

General Information

Lead Inquiry

Applicant Screening

General Information

PURE Centralized Leasing helps to maintain consistency and communication across all areas of the leasing process and ensures that all Residential Rental Applications are managed in accordance with PURE policies in the order that they are received and completed.

The Leasing Specialist fields all inquiries and communicates with all leads for each property listing, and is responsible for documenting these interactions in Tenant Turner, ShowMojo, and the applicable PMS.

Lead Inquiry

When a lead inquires about a property that they located on a listing site - e.g., Zillow - they are invited via an automated message to answer pre-qualification questions presented in accordance with PURE guidelines, and, if they are pre-qualified, to schedule an appointment for a self-showing of the property. Leads who do not pre-qualify are automatically notified that they are ineligible to move forward with scheduling a self-showing.

Pre-qualified leads, after scheduling the appointment, are alerted through both email and text message notifications in addition to receiving a calendar invitation; notifications will include all details regarding the appointment's date, time, and the property's address. Leads are authorized and able to access the property for a self-showing only at the time of their scheduled appointment with a time-sensitive unique SentriLock electronic lockbox code. 


As with other calls, when a lead calls any PURE office they are directed through the interactive voice response system (IVR) menu of options. Leads will select the Leasing option from the IVR menu, and, should they request to speak with a representative, are forwarded to the Leasing team for assistance. The Leasing team may also communicate with leads via email, using the assigned office email address for Leasing.

Applicant Screening

All applicants are screened utilizing VeriFast and TransUnion to verify identity, income, employment, credit eligibility, criminal, bankruptcy, non-sufficient funds transactions, and eviction records. Self-employed applicants may also access these options by providing tax documentation and by connecting their bank account to VeriFast. Additional rental eligibility requirements apply to self-employed applicants.

All applicants, regardless of whether or not they have a pet or assistance animal, are required to complete a PetScreening profile to comply with PURE company policies. If applicable, the applicant's pet or assistance animal will be screened via PetScreening as a part of this process.

Application Inquiries

Important Notes:
Conduct all business in accordance with company policies and procedures, Fair Housing, Americans with Disabilities Act, Fair Credit Reporting Act, applicable state statutes, and all other laws pertaining to residential rentals, whether local, state, or federal.

As an unlicensed Leasing Specialist, there are limitations imposed by each state regulating what may or may not be done. As a rule of thumb, do not:

  • provide any information regarding the property that is not provided in the Property Listing.

  • make any comments regarding crime rates, the quality of schools, or information regarding the neighborhood.

  • negotiate any terms including but not limited to price, pets, security deposit, or lease term.

All communications must align with the PURE Way Brand + Messaging + Communications Guidebook, available within the PURE Way Resource Center.

🛑 CO: What is a PTSR? **LINK ABOVE**

PTSR is a consumer report prepared at the request of a prospective tenant that includes information provided by a consumer reporting agency. To determine the validity of the PTSR, use the guidelines below.

A valid PTSR includes the following information:

  • Name

  • Contact Information

  • Verification of employment and income

  • Last known address


  • For each jurisdiction indicated in the consumer report as a prior residence of the prospective tenant, regardless of whether the residence is reported by the prospective tenant or by the consumer reporting agency preparing the consumer report.

○ A rental and credit history report for the prospective tenant that complies within section 38-12-904 (1)(a) concerning a landlord’s consideration of a prospective tenant’s rental history; and

○ A criminal history record check for all federal, state, and local convictions of the prospective tenant that complies with section 38-12-904(1.5)(b) concerning a landlord’s consideration of a prospective tenant’s arrest records.

  • The screening report was completed within the previous thirty days;

  • The screening report is made directly available to the landlord by the consumer reporting agency for use in the rental application process or provided through a third-party website that regularly engages in the business of providing consumer reports and complies with all state and federal laws pertaining to use and disclosure of information contained in a consumer report by a consumer reporting agency;

  • The screening report is made available to the landlord at no cost to access or use in the rental application process; and

  • A statement for the prospective tenant that there has not been a material change in the information in the screening report, including the prospective tenant’s name, address, bankruptcy status, criminal history, or eviction history, since the report was generated.


Note: A credit report is not required for Subsidy applicants.

If

|

Then

No

|

Continue to Review Application Criteria.

Yes 


Note: Subsidized applicants are screened under a different criteria (income and criminal only) as per local regulations.

"Housing subsidy" means any portion of a rental payment that is derived from a public or private assistance, grant, or loan program and that is paid by the program directly or indirectly, or on behalf of a tenant to the landlord.

VeriFast Screening Information

VeriFast is a third party that provides a safe, easy way to verify identity, income, and employment. Each Applicant must go through the verification process through VeriFast.

1. The Leasing Specialist provides the VeriFast Verification link to the Applicant in the Application Verified Email.
2. There is a separate link for self-employed applicants. If the applicant group is a mixture of self-employed and payroll, send the appropriate link to each. Then combine the profiles in VeriFast for an accurate recommendation. Note: Some offices have additional links for subsidized housing, multi-family housing, city, etc.

a. To access links for your office, log in to VeriFast and select Applications from the menu.

3. Upon completion, an email notification is sent to the Leasing Specialist.

VeriFast Applicant Screening Requirements

  • The Applicant has 24 hours to complete the verification process.

○ When there are co-applicants, the primary Applicant will initiate the process by clicking the link and providing the contact information for each co-applicant.

  • All Applicants are required to provide proof of identity with a government-issued photo ID and complete the facial recognition process.

  • Applicants will complete the following process to complete employment, income, and NSF activity verification:

○ Directly connect with their bank account. If the applicant cannot do this, they may upload their last 3 bank statements. Access to multiple bank accounts is permitted.

○ Log in to their payroll account online. When an applicant does not have an online payroll account, they may upload their last 2 pay stubs. Pay stubs must be in PDF format and not in a picture format. (VeriFast is unable to extract metadata from an image.)

○ Self-employed applicants will be required to upload their most recent tax return in place of pay stubs.


VeriFast Screening Instructions

1. Review the Applicant’s completed VeriFast screening

2. Click the link in the email notification from VeriFast or log in to the VeriFast Dashboard to locate the record.

3. Check the following: (This information will be taken into consideration when determining the final Application Recommendation later in the process.)

a. ID Verification: This will say Verified or Unverified. (Unverified is a detection of fraud.)

b. Verify that the rental rate provided is accurate. If it is not, click Edit and enter the correct amount.

c. Income to Rent Requirement: An applicant’s combined income must meet the income requirement as set forth in the screening criteria. A guarantor’s income must be at least 4 times the rent.

i. 🛑 Seattle, WA: For applicants that applied for a property in Seattle, WA, income verified during the current month must be accepted even if they do not have a job or are not expecting any income in the future.

ii. 🛑 OR: The maximum income requirement is 3x for an applicant(s) and guarantor.

1. There are 6 VeriFast accounts for OR.

a. Portland, OR-Financially Responsible: Income requirement is 2.5x.*

b. Non-Financially Responsible: Only verifies identity.

c. OR-Financially Responsible: Income requirement for applicant and guarantor is 3x.

d. Self-employed Portland: Income requirement is *2.5x or 6x avg bank balance.

e. OR Self-employed: Income requirement is 3x or 6x avg bank balance.


iii. 🛑 Portland, OR: *The income requirement varies between 2x - 2.5x for an applicant(s) based on the rental rate. Refer to Current Income and Rent Limits-Portland Housing Bureau for instructions.

d. Go to Self-employed Income Verification if the Applicant is self-employed.

e. NSF: Verify NSF activity is less than 5.

🛑 CO: Not applicable to Subsidized applicants.


Housing Assistance/Section 8

🛑 States or cities that require Section 8 acceptance: CO, WA, CA, & OR.

1. If the applicant indicated they are on housing assistance/ section 8 and the property accepts housing assistance/ section 8:

a. Obtain a copy of the section 8 voucher from the applicant.

b. Review the voucher to confirm it has not expired. If it has expired, the applicant must provide an updated copy.

c. Upload the voucher to the applicant profile in VeriFast if the applicant has not done so already.

d. Identify the amount of rent that will be paid by the agency on the voucher. This will be considered additional monthly income.

i. 🛑 CA: Some vouchers may only provide the number of bedrooms they are approved for. If this is the case, follow the steps below to determine the tenant’s portion of the rent.

1. Obtain additional supporting documentation outlining the zip code, number of bedrooms, and the amount paid by the housing authority.

2. Confirm the property applied for has the amount of bedrooms or fewer as specified on the voucher.

3. Using the supporting documentation, determine the portion paid by the tenant.

ii. 🛑 Santa Cruz County, CA:

1. Contact the Housing Authority to request an estimate for the portion that the tenant and Housing Authority are responsible for. Janet Cantolan 831-454-9455 Ext 217, leasing.specialist@hacosantacruz.org, www.hacosantacruz.org

e. Determining whether the applicant meets the income requirement varies by jurisdiction.

i. Standard process unless otherwise noted: Add the income from the voucher to the verified income amount. Determine the amount of income required as per your application guidelines. If the applicant’s total verified income exceeds that amount then they meet the income qualification.

ii. 🛑 CO: Review the voucher to determine how much rent the applicant is responsible for. Multiply that amount by 2. This is the income requirement. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. If not, edit the rent.

iii. 🛑 OR: Review the voucher to determine how much rent the applicant is responsible for. Multiply that amount by 3. If the property is in the City of Portland, refer to Current Income and Rent Limits-Portland Housing Bureau for income requirement details. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. If not, edit the rent.

iv. 🛑 CA: Review the voucher to determine how much rent the applicant is responsible for. Multiply that amount by 3. This is the income requirement. The portion paid for by the housing assistance provider is considered verifiable income. Add this income to any other verifiable income, if any. If the amount is equal to or greater than the income requirement then they meet the income requirement. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. If not, edit the rent.

v. 🛑 CA North Bay Multi-family: Review the voucher to determine how much rent the applicant is responsible for. Multiply that amount by 2. This is the income requirement. The portion paid for by the housing assistance provider is considered verifiable income. Add this income to any other verifiable income, if any. If the amount is equal to or greater than the income requirement then they meet the income requirement. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. If not, edit the rent.

vi. 🛑 WA: Check AppFolio to verify which Housing Assistance programs can be accepted for the property. Reach out to the Property Manager if this cannot be verified in AppFolio. (Some HA programs cannot be used in certain municipalities.) Review the voucher to determine how much rent the applicant is responsible for. Multiply that amount by 3. This is the income requirement. Verify the rent on the application in VeriFast equals the Tenant’s portion of the rent noted on the application. If not, edit the rent.

f. Upload a copy of the section 8 voucher to the applicant in the PMS.

a. Add a Note on the application in the PMS indicating the additional income verified outside of VeriFast as their initial income reported (excluding section 8) may not have met the income requirement.


Guarantor Screening Through VeriFast

A guarantor is required when an Applicant’s Screening Recommendation through TransUnion is returned with a “Refer” status or if the applicant does not meet the income requirements.

The guarantor’s profile must be linked to the Applicant’s profile.

A link is generated from the VeriFast dashboard and sent to the Applicant to provide to their guarantor.

Note: A guarantor’s income requirement is 4x the monthly rental amount. The approval process for a guarantor is the same as for an Applicant.

🛑 Exception-OR: A guarantor’s income requirement is 3x the monthly rental amount.


Upload Applicant or Guarantor VeriFast Screening Report

2. Select “Download Report as PDF” and select all checkboxes.
3. Upload the report to the Application Record in the Property Management System (PMS).

Self-employed Income Verification

Self-employed Applicants are required to complete the following through VeriFast:

Calculating Self-Employed Income:

If

|

Then

The previous year's filed tax return is provided,

|

Divide the Adjustable Gross Income (line 11 on Form 1040) by 12 months for the monthly income.

Bank verification through VeriFast is provided

The average bank balance must be at least 6 times the rental rate.

Does the self-employed Applicant meet the income requirement?

If

|

The Applicant provided a copy of the previous year’s tax return

Their monthly income is equal to or greater than the income requirement noted in the application guidelines or local ordinance

Their average bank balance is equal to or greater than 6x the monthly rental amount.

🛑 CA Application Recommendation Re-Evaluation for Government Subsidized Applicants Under-SB 267

This section is to be used to re-evaluate an applicant that is a government rent subsidy recipient that chose to exercise their rights under SB 267.

SB 267 prohibits a landlord, in instances where there is a government rent subsidy from using a person’s credit history as part of the rental application process without offering the applicant the option, at the applicant’s discretion, of providing lawful, verifiable alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay the portion of the rent to be paid by the tenant, including but not limited to, government benefit payments, pay records, and bank statements. If the applicant elects to provide alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay, the landlord must reasonably consider that alternative evidence in lieu of the person’s credit history in determining whether to offer the rental accommodation to the applicant.

This right only applies to applicants that were declined or conditionally approved (guarantor) solely based on credit/ResidentScore. Applicants have 24 hours from the date of receiving the adverse action letter to submit notice.

Notify the Applicant

Once an Application Recommendation has been confirmed, the next step is to inform the applicant of the results and next steps, if any.

Define Terms

For approved or conditionally approved applicants define the Residential Application Offer terms. Follow the steps below.

1. HOA/COA Application Requirements


Some Homeowner Associations and Condominium Owner Associations require applicants to submit an application and pay an application fee to them. Association applications are only processed when an applicant’s application is Approved or Conditionally Approved/Low Accept.

The Property Listing will identify whether there is a requirement and additional details can be found on the Property in the Property Management System (PMS). If additional instruction is needed, contact the Property Manager.

The applicant will be provided with additional information when they are notified their application is Accepted or Conditionally Approved/Low Accepted. In addition to the notification, call the applicant to ensure they understand the next steps. Facilitate the application process between the applicant and the association. Time is of the essence. If issues arise, notify the Property Manager.

2. Additional Terms

For approved and conditionally approved applications, confirmation of the following terms must be completed:

  • Lease Start Date (No earlier than the date provided by the property manager and no later than 10 days from the lease draft date or available date. If the applicant is on housing assistance or if there are additional tasks required by the HOA/COA, this date will be determined once these requirements are fulfilled.)

  • RBP Selection

  • SDRP Enrollment Selection (Only offered to Approved applicants.)

  • First Full Month’s Rent Due on or Before Lease Signing

  • Move-in Funds Due, (May Include Pet Administration Fee, Monthly Pet Fee, Security Deposit, Administrative Fee).

  • Conditional requirements such as a higher deposit or guarantor.

  • Check property listing to determine whether a move-in special or additional fees/services apply.


3. Adverse Action Letters (When applicable)
Adverse Action Letters are required when an applicant is declined or is offered conditional approval (requires a higher deposit or a guarantor).

If an application is declined or Low Accept through TransUnion, the Adverse Action Letter must be generated through TransUnion and attached to the email notification noted in the process below. Each applicant must receive a separate email with their personalized Adverse Action Letter attached.

To generate an Adverse Action Letter in TransUnion:

🛑 Saint Paul & Minneapolis, MN Exception: Do not use TransUnion’s Adverse Action Letter for properties located in Saint Paul, MN or Minneapolis, MN.

1. From the applicant’s profile click Recommendation Letters

2. Click Create PDF to download

a. When there is more than 1 applicant, the PDF will need to be separated into separate letters per applicant.

i. Use Ilovepdf.com to separate the PDF Document into multiple documents.

3. Upload the letters to the applicant’s profile in the Property Management System (PMS)

If an application is declined for any reason outside of TransUnion, the Adverse Action Letter requirements are a part of the email notification noted in the matrix below.

Applicants that were declined solely due to outstanding utility-type debts found on their credit report may opt to pay the debt(s) in full and provide proof of payment within 1 business day of being notified of the application decision. Proof of payment must be from the creditor or the collections agency indicating the balance is paid in full. Upon review, the applicant will no longer be declined for this reason and will need to be evaluated to determine the new application recommendation. This allowance is included in the application and on the AAL, assuming this is the only cause for the denial outlined.

🛑 Exception: MN

Exception: It is up to the applicant if they want to demonstrate a history of successful rent payments if they do not meet the rent-to-income requirement. We will require that they provide proof of rental history. It must be in writing from the previous landlord. If it is from a property management company, it must be an official company document. If it is a private owner, it must be signed. An acceptable rental history consists of 2 solid years of rental payments from the date the application was submitted with no late payments. This information must be provided to us within 1 business day of notifying them of the initial screening decision. Upon review and approval of rental history, this requirement will no longer be taken into consideration. Additional evaluation will need to be performed to determine the final application recommendation. This allowance is not publicized as it is not required to be by law.

🛑 Exception: CA Government Subsidized Applicants

SB 267 prohibits a landlord, in instances where there is a government rent subsidy from using a person’s credit history as part of the rental application process without offering the applicant the option, at the applicant’s discretion, of providing lawful, verifiable alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay the portion of the rent to be paid by the tenant, including but not limited to, government benefit payments, pay records, and bank statements. If the applicant elects to provide alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay, the landlord must reasonably consider that alternative evidence in lieu of the person’s credit history in determining whether to offer the rental accommodation to the applicant. This right only applies to applicants that were declined or conditionally approved (guarantor) based solely on credit/ResidentScore. Applicants have 24 hours from the date of receiving the adverse action letter to submit evidence.

🛑 Exception: Seattle/Tacoma WA Office

If the applicant requests to set up a payment plan for the security deposit, obtain approval from the Property Manager. The Property Manager will be responsible for setting up the terms of the payment plan. Certain cities have ordinances related to requirements surrounding payment plans.

🛑 Exception: OR

Upon request, applicants are permitted to set up a 3 month payment plan when approved with the condition of paying a security deposit equal to 1.5 times the rent. Only the .5 portion of the security is eligible for a payment plan. Notify the Property Manager of the applicant’s request. Let the applicant know that the Property Manager will coordinate the details with them directly.

There are additional HOA or COA requirements.

|

1. Facilitate the application process between the applicant and the HOA/COA.
2. Update the Property Listing Status to “Application Pending” in Tenant Turner.
3. Upon approval from HOA/COA:

a. Upload a copy of the approval to the applicant’s profile in the PMS.

b. Email the approved Applicant the Next Steps for Lease Preparation and copy the Property Manager.


🛑 OR: Email the approved applicant the Next Steps for Lease Preparation - OR and copy the Property Manager.

🛑 WA: Email the approved applicant the Next Steps for Lease Preparation - WA and copy the Property Manager.

🛑 Subsidized CO Applicants: Use the Next Steps for Lease Preparation-Subsidized CO Applicant email and copy the Property Manager.

4. Attach the email to the Applicant record, and add a note within the Property Management System (PMS).
5. Go to Notify the Investor Client. (Complete this step after the HOA/COA requirement has been completed.)

🛑 CA Applicant is a Government Subsidy recipient

AND

Declined due to ResidentScore only

OR

Conditionally Approved (Guarantor Required) due to ResidentScore only

AND

Applicant chose to exercise rights under SB 267 by providing evidence of reasonable ability to pay their portion of the rent and bypass the ResidentScore requirement.

|

1. Determine whether the applicant met the income requirement by reviewing the VeriFast results.
2. Upload any additional evidence provided in VeriFast to the application in the PMS. Add a note in the PMS explaining the situation.
3. Proceed to CA Government Subsidized Applicants -SB 267 Review section.

🛑 OR Applicant is declined

AND

Applicant appeals the denial of the application

AND

The appeal is received within 30 days of the application denial


|

1. Email the Application Denial Appeal - OR template to the applicant and copy the Operations Manager.
2. Reach out to the Operations Manager to confirm they received the email.
3. The Operations Manager completes the appeals process.
4. If the Operations Manager rescinds the denial, the application will be active for 3 months following the date a landlord approves an application and may not charge another application during that time-frame. They are required to self-certify that no conditions have materially changed from those described in the application.

Notify the Investor Client

Send Applicant Approved-Client Notification regarding the approved or conditionally approved application and copy the Property Manager on the email.

The Property Manager begins the Residential Rental Agreement Process for Applicants moving forward.

Notify Additional Applicants in Waiting

Notify all additional Applicants in waiting that the property has become unavailable.

If

|

Then

The Applicant chooses to transfer their application to another property,

|

1. Send Applicants in Waiting - Property Rented.
2. Call or text the applicant to let them know the property is no longer available. See if they are interested in transferring their application to another property.
3. Update the application address in the Property Management System (PMS).
4. Go to Application Received.

The Applicant chooses to close their application,

AND

Requests a refund,

|

1. Send Applicants in Waiting - Property Rented.
2. Call or text the applicant to let them know the property is no longer available. See if they are interested in transferring their application to another property.
3. Process the application fee refund.
4. Update the status of the application in the Property Management System (PMS).

The Applicant chooses to keep the application open for 30 days from the date they first applied,

🛑 OR: The application is valid for 60 days.

|

Update the status of the application in the Property Management System (PMS).

The applicant is non-responsive after 7 days,

|

1. Update the application status in the Property Management System (PMS).
2. Process the application fee refund.
3. Update the status of the application in the Property Management System (PMS).

Adverse Action Email Bounceback

If

|

Then

An email containing the Adverse Action Letter messaging to an applicant bounces back,

|

1. . Call the applicant to verify their email address.
2. Update the applicant's email address and send the email to the updated address.

An email containing the Adverse Action Letter messaging to an applicant bounces back a second time,

|

Forward the email with the Adverse Action Letter to the Property Manager with a request to mail the Adverse Action Letter to the applicant via USPS in accordance with regulations.

Update the Property Listing Status

Update the Property Listing Status to “Application Pending”

Only update the Property Listing Status to “Application Pending” when an application has been approved or approved with conditions.

A property statused “Application Pending” will not permit the scheduling of showings.

In Tenant Turner:

1. Select Rentals from the menu

2. Click on the property

3. Select Settings,

4. Under the Viewing section, select the Waitlist Reason as Application Pending (Do not turn off self showing slider in Tenant Turner)

5. Place the following verbiage:

Thank you for your interest in our property. We currently have an approved application for this property. To help you continue your search, please reference our website for more available properties. [OFFICE WEBSITE LINK]

6. Click Save.

In ShowMojo: This is not applicable as it does not offer the ability to change the status.


Update the Property Listing Status to “Active”

If an approved applicant does not follow through with signing a lease, promptly update the Property Listing Status back to active.

In Tenant Turner:

1. Select Rentals from the menu

2. Click on the property

3. Select Settings

4. Under the Viewing section, delete Application Pending.

5. Click Save.

In ShowMojo: This is not applicable as it does not offer the option to change the status. It is either active or inactive.

Application Refund Requests

Application fees are only refundable if we did not screen the Applicant through TransUnion or VeriFast or under special circumstances to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

The most common reasons include:

  • An Applicant changed their mind before screening

  • Another application was processed and approved.

To submit an application refund request, email the Team Leader.
Include the following information:

1. Name of Applicant(s)

2. Reason for refund

3. Amount of requested refund

4. Office/branch location

5. Date Application Fee was collected


The Team Leader will review the application fee refund request.

If

|

Then

The Team Leader denies the refund 

|

1. Notify the Leasing Specialist that the request has been denied.
2. The Leasing Specialist will send the Refund Request Denial to the applicant.

The Team Leader approves the refund

|

1. Notify the Leasing Specialist that the request has been approved.
2. Start the refund process in PMS on any day but Thursdays. (Accounting will complete the refund process every Thursday.)
3. The Leasing Specialist will send the Refund Request Approved email to the applicant.

a. 🛑 CO: Notification to the applicant regarding a refund for applicants that provided a valid PTSR that paid an application fee should have already been notified at this point. (Templates used: CO Refund Request Approved-Valid PTSR.)

b. 🛑 OR: Notification to the applicant that we are closing their application and refunding the application fee due to not having a financially responsible party. Email the applicant Portland, OR Refund Request - Approved template.

8. Use of Credit History in Application Process (SB 267). Effective 1/1/24. This law prohibits a landlord, in instances where there is a government rent subsidy (e.g., Section 8 voucher) from using a person’s credit history as part of the rental application process without offering the applicant the option, at the applicant’s discretion, of providing lawful, verifiable alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay the portion of the rent to be paid by the tenant, including but not limited to, government benefit payments, pay records, and bank statements. If applicant elects to provide alternative evidence of reasonable ability to pay, the landlord must provide the applicant reasonable time to respond with that alternative evidence and reasonably consider that alternative evidence in lieu of the person’s credit history in determining whether to offer the rental accommodation to the applicant. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the landlord may still request information or documentation to verify employment, to request landlord references, and to verify the identity of the applicant.

If not complete, we must give them 24 hours to complete before moving on to the next one. If they decide to transfer the application they will be first in line.

5. Portland - must advertise the property for 72 hours. If someone applies prior to the 72 hours they are penalized by 8 hours. First come first serve is required. If not complete, we must give them 24 hours to complete before moving on to the next one. If they decide to transfer the application they will be first in line. During the 72 hour period the property is waitlisted but it can be shown upon request.

6. Application is valid for 60 days.

7. Cannot charge one-time fees including admin fee and initial pet fee.

8. RBP and SDRP are optional.

9. Applicant Identification. A Landlord may not reject an application as incomplete because an Applicant or member of the Applicant’s household does not produce a social security number or prove lawful presence in the U.S. A Landlord may not inquire about the immigration status of a member of the Applicant’s household or require proof of their lawful presence in the U.S. A Landlord must accept any of the following, or a combination thereof, to verify the name, date of birth and photo of the Applicant:

a. Evidence of Social Security Number (SSN Card);

b. Valid Permanent Resident Alien Registration Receipt Card;

c. Immigrant Visa;

d. Individual Tax Payer Identification Number (ITIN);

e. Non-immigrant visa;

f. Any government-issued identification regardless of expiration date; or

g. Any non-governmental identification or combination of identifications that would permit a reasonable verification of identity.

10. Deposits are capped at 1.5x.

11. HOA’s are able to charge deposits even though the law does not allow it.

12. We cannot consider evictions between 4/1/20-3/1/22, the COVID emergency period.

13. We cannot consider a conviction for a crime that is no longer illegal.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KngNhGM5kGZZzAQw4scXERn-ZNygt06dYWHXOc5vk9w/edit#:~:text=https%3A//olis.oregonlegislature.gov/liz/2019I1/Downloads/CommitteeMeetingDocument/227319

14. Can only go back 7 years for felony convictions, and any convictions that happened between within the last seven years must have an individual assessment performed. Not saying we cant deny based on felony convictions (outside of things that are no longer illegal in Oregon), but we must:

Consideration of Supplemental Evidence; Individual Assessment. In evaluating an Applicant using the Individual Assessment, a Landlord must accept and consider all Supplemental Evidence, if any is provided with a completed application to explain, justify or negate the relevance of potentially negative information revealed by screening. In evaluating an Applicant using the Individual Assessment, the Landlord must also consider:

a. The nature and severity of the incidents that would lead to a denial;

b. The number and type of the incidents;

c. The time that has elapsed since the date the incidents occurred; and

d. The age of the individual at the time the incidents occurred.

15. Max income requirement for applicant and guarantor is 3x. We can use this as our criteria, but we have to do a manual individual assessment before denying the application.

Monthly income must be 2 times the monthly stated rent or 2.5 times the monthly stated rent if the monthly rent amount is below the maximum monthly rent for a household earning no more than 80% of the median household income as published annually by the Portland Housing Bureau. https://www.multifamilynw.org/PHB_Rent_Income_Limits

16. Appeals. A Landlord must offer the Applicant an opportunity for appeal for 30 days following the denial of an Application. The Landlord’s appeal process must:

a. Provide the Applicant the opportunity to correct, refute or explain negative information that formed the basis of the Landlord’s denial;

b. Prequalify the Applicant for rental opportunities at the Landlord’s properties in the City of Portland for the 3 months following the date a Landlord approves an application reviewed on appeal; and

c. Waive the Applicant’s screening fee for the 3 months following the approved appeal. Prior to waiving the screening fee, the Landlord may require the Applicant to self-certify that no conditions have materially changed from those described in the Landlord’s approved application.

17. When presented with a conditional approval or a guarantor- the applicant will have no less than 48 hours after the communication of conditional approval to accept or decline this opportunity.

18. In Portland, rent to income will range 2x- 2.5x based on rent amount.

https://www.multifamilynw.org/PHB_Rent_Income_Limits##

19. An applicant is considered either Financially Responsible or Non-Financially Responsible. We can only check the Non-Financially Responsible party for Criminal, IDV, and Petscreening.

Call Escalation 

If

|

Then

A caller is requesting to speak to a Manager or their Property Manager,

|

“We understand that you are upset, and I’m here to help. Please tell me more about the issue so I can assist you....  repeat their issue to confirm understanding). Please allow us to have the opportunity to work on a resolution as quickly as possible.”

If the caller is an approved applicant who is working with a Property Manager, provide the caller with the Property Manager’s contact information.


If the caller is still insisting on speaking to a “Manager” or “Supervisor,” place the caller on hold.

Notify your Team Leader that a caller is requesting a “supervisor.”

The Team Leader will attempt to de-escalate the caller. The Team Leader will document the
call in Tenant Turner, Showmojo, or the PMS.


If there is no Team Leader on shift and you are unable to de-escalate the call yourself, email the Director of Leasing for support. 

A caller is repeatedly calling for an update on their application

|

“We understand that you are anxious to move forward with the application process. Please allow us to have the opportunity to work on a resolution as quickly as possible. By calling back, we are not able to work on your request. We will follow up with you no later than (day/time) with an update. We appreciate your patience and understanding.”

A threatening or harassing caller

|

Immediately email your Team Leader and the Director of Leasing.

"We understand your concerns. We are actively working on a resolution. Please allow us to have the opportunity to work on a resolution as quickly as possible. By calling back, we are not able to work on your request. We will follow up with you no later than (day/time) with an update. We appreciate your patience and understanding”

If the caller is cursing, let the caller know that you would like to continue the conversation to resolve their concern but if they continue to curse and be disrespectful you will have no choice but to hang up the phone. This is a one time warning. If they continue to curse then hang up the phone.

General Responsibilities

At the beginning of each shift, review all open Residential Rental Applications, Messages, emails, and voicemails.

Throughout your shift, remain aware of incoming Residential Rental Applications, Messages, and emails and actively follow up with the prospective residents and/or applicants.

Near the end of each shift before clocking out, review all open activities to ensure all commitments were completed for the day.

Listing & Application Inquiries

Important Notes:

Conduct all business in accordance with company policies and procedures, Fair Housing, Americans with Disabilities Act, Fair Credit Reporting Act, applicable state statutes, and all other laws pertaining to residential rentals, whether local, state, or federal.

There are limitations imposed by each state regulating what an unlicensed Leasing Specialist may or may not do.

As a rule of thumb, do not:

  • provide any information regarding the property that is not provided in the Property Listing.

  • make any comments regarding crime rates, the quality of schools, or information regarding the neighborhood.

  • negotiate any terms including but not limited to price, pets, security deposit, or lease term.

The Leasing Specialist monitors notifications from Tenant Turner or ShowMojo, and the Email Inbox for New Listing Inquiries.

All communications generated by PURE Property Management Leasing are defined by the Application & Leasing Communication Guidelines.

All communications must align with the PURE Way Brand + Messaging + Communications Guidebook.


Phone Communication

Inbound Phone Inquiries

When a prospect contacts an office, they will select the extension for Leasing. The call will be routed to Tenant Turner or Showmojo. If the prospect indicates they need additional assistance, the call will be routed to a Leasing Queue and directed to the applicable Leasing Specialist(s) for assistance.

Note: The number for the Leasing Queue is unpublished.

It is best practice to answer all calls within the first 3 rings. If the call is not answered, it will go to voicemail. All calls should be returned within 30 minutes from the time the voicemail was left.

Inquiry Voicemails

It is your responsibility to regularly retrieve voicemail messages and return the calls within the established time. Voicemails must be returned in no more than 30 minutes. Document all outbound call details on the Lead Page under the note section in Tenant Turner.

Call Greetings

Use the following scripts to Greet inbound and outbound calls.

Inbound Call Greeting

“Thank you for calling the PURE Property Management [OFFICE NAME] Leasing Department. Can you please state your name and the property in which you are interested?”

1. Locate the lead page in Tenant Turner.

2. Check the additional info to prepare for any specific questions or negative feedback.

3. All outbound calls must be documented on the Lead Page under the Lead Notes section in Tenant Turner.

Continue to Lead Talking Points.

Outbound Call Greeting

1. Locate the lead page in Tenant Turner.

2. Check the additional info to prepare for any specific questions or negative feedback.

3. All outbound calls must be documented on the Lead Page under the Lead Notes section in Tenant Turner.

“Hi, this is [YOUR NAME]; I’m reaching out on behalf of PURE Property Management [OFFICE NAME] Leasing Department. I am looking to speak with [Lead Name].”

Add a Note on the Lead Record

Notes are to be added when there are communications outside of automated communications.


For example, a Note will need to be created when you communicate with a Property Manager or when an applicant calls with questions.


In Tenant Turner: From the lead record, locate the Notes section and click Add. Then add the note.

If the prospect inquires: What is the Application process?

|

The application process is as follows:

  • Identity, credit, criminal, eviction history, employment, and income will be verified

  • Direct them to the website to apply online and review the application guidelines and screening criteria

  • Each adult must complete an application and pay the application fee

  • Complete applications are processed on a first-come, first-served basis

  • Applicants are required to complete a profile with PetScreening.com and complete a profile in VeriFast to verify their identity, employment, and income

  • Do not say anything that is not outlined in the application

The prospect is requesting a link to an application,

|

Refer the applicant to the website to apply online.


The prospect is giving negative feedback about a property, or part of their application experience,

|

It is important to respond with empathy by acknowledging and thanking them for their feedback.

When the feedback is an emergency maintenance issue, notify the Property Manager immediately by email with the detailed information. *If the office has a Turn/Rehab Specialist, notify them in place of the Property Manager.

If they are not interested in a property because it is not a good fit for them, invite them to view other listings available and provide them with a link to the listings.

The prospect has specific questions regarding the property.

Examples of common questions:

  • Can I have a pet?

  • What are the pet fees?

  • What services are included?

  • Do you accept housing assistance?

  • When is the property available?

  • When can I move in?


|

Important Note: Do not communicate any information that is not provided in writing by the Property Manager or is not in accordance with the PURE Way.

1. Search the marketing listing for the answer to the question.
2. Review the Residential Rental Application for the answer to the question.
3. If the answer cannot be found, reach out to the Property Manager for assistance.


If a prospect asks: “Are pet screening fees (ever) refundable?”

|

No, Pet Screening fees are handled exclusively by petscreening.com


If a prospect asks “What is PURE's policy on animals and pets?”

|

Review details regarding PURE Property Management’s Animal Program as defined in the Animal Program Overview.

If a prospect asks “How do I apply to a property that is not on the website?"

|

1. Obtain approval by the Property Manager or the Business Development Representative before proceeding.
2. Upon approval, send the application link from the Property Management System (PMS) to the applicant.

If a prospect asks “What do I need to do to apply for a property if I do not have a SSN?”

|

Every adult occupant must submit an application and must provide proof of permitted stay in the US with a Visa. They will be screened under the screening criteria noted in the application. Because they do not have a Social Security Number, they will not have any credit. Assuming they meet all of the screening requirements except for the ResidentScore, they will be required to provide a qualified guarantor.

If a prospect asks “Do you accept section 8/housing assistance and how will my income be calculated?”

🛑 Some jurisdictions require landlords to accept housing assistance and some have a regulated application process and screening requirements.

 Refer to the Centralized Leasing-Residential Listing Inquiries and Applications section.

|

1. Check the property listing to determine whether the property accepts housing assistance.
2. If housing assistance is accepted, they will need to submit a copy of their voucher. (The voucher indicates the amount the agency will pay, the amount the resident will pay, and the maximum rental rate.)
3. The amount paid by the agency will be added to their verified income through VeriFast to determine if they meet the income criteria.
